name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We got to know gloomy news around the world this weekend. In Turkey, 44 people died in a bomb attack outside the Beşiktas Istanbul stadium. In Somalia, in the port of Mogadishu, 30 people were killed in a bomb attack. In Egypt, a bomb was dropped at the Coptic Church of Cairo, where 25 people died. These are three more attacks in our year 2016, in which the entire world is hit practically every day by the geissl of terrorism. There is no difference in this terrorism. He meets us in Europe as well as in Africa, in Asia as well as in America. He's meeting us all! He usually meets unruly people, and he meets Christians as well as Muslims. Men, women and, in particularly disgusting form, children are victims of these terrorist attacks. I believe that I speak on behalf of all of you when I say here that there is no justification for anything that this terrorist represents. Whether they call themselves Da'esh, Al-Qaeda, Al-Shabaab or Freedom Falcons, or all the other terrorist organizations, whatever their names, they are fighting tolerance, solidarity, friendship and humanity in the world. They want to spread fear and intimidate us. Therefore, the answer to this terror can only be that we continue to stand by our values of tolerance, solidarity, friendship and humanity. This will be more difficult with every bomb attack and every victim, but if we stopped, ladies and gentlemen, by these values, then the terrorists would have won. That is why I would ask you to make a contribution by the European Parliament to continue this fight for tolerance and respect and against this inhuman terror. We should also not fail to mention that, for example, in the Nigerian uyo through a collapsed church roof 160 people died during a church service. This is all news that is profoundly shaking us, and on behalf of all the Members of this House, I would like to express our deepest sympathy to the victims and their families. Ladies and gentlemen! I would also like to inform you that today I sent two letters — one to the Egyptian President and one to the Prime Minister of Ethiopia. You will recall a year ago we discussed the case of Irish citizen Ibrahim Halawa, a 17-year-old young man, who took part in a demonstration in Cairo, who was then arrested, was charged as a minor and is now 21 years old. Now the trial begins, and the young man is threatened with the death penalty because he took part in a demonstration. I call on the Egyptian Government to honour its human obligation to treat this young man as a minor at the time of his arrest. Last week, an opposition politician from Ethiopia, Dr Merera Gudina, met a number of colleagues from this House to report on the serious and dramatic situation in Ethiopia. He was arrested on his return and is being held in an unknown location. I have called on the Government of Ethiopia to release Dr Gudina immediately.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this partsession, as drawn up by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting of Thursday 8 December 2016, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. –  Mr President, we want to raise this question to have a full debate on the AFCO Corbett report on the General Revision of the Rules of Procedure. We think that it is a very important document for the further work of our Parliament, as it is about how we work together and the rights and duties of all of us here in the House. Therefore, we would like to have this debate as a full plenary debate and we request, on behalf of our Group, to have it as a roll call vote.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we support Mr Scholz's proposal. Indeed, this Parliament has a fairly common way of insisting on the transparency of the other institutions of the European Union. It does not happen every day to review, fundamentally, the rules of procedure of this Parliament. I think it is only normal for us to debate at least once in plenary how this Parliament, which is the European Citizens' Parliament, works. I think it is quite appropriate that we have this debate publicly.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: (Parliament adopted the request) The Group of the European Union has requested that a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Aleppo be placed on the agenda as the first item in the afternoon.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I propose a debate on Aleppo on Wednesday, the first debate this afternoon. There is a dramatic humanitarian situation in Aleppo, and I think the truth must be restored. Today, al-Nosra rebels are preventing Syria from establishing humanitarian corridors, and it is therefore important today to ensure that the situation in Aleppo is well understood. There is a need for a substantive debate on this subject. I suggest that we can discuss it precisely, because Aleppo is the beginning of the liberation of Syria, it is a very important point, and I think that Parliament must be able to speak on this subject.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Mr President, I wanted to highlight this great liberation day for Syria. Let us say once and for all the truth about East Aleppo, about manipulation, propaganda against the rule of law, democracy, morals, but above all, against truth. It is therefore very important that this debate take place.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Since no one wants to speak against the motion, I will now put the proposal of the ENF Group to the vote. (Parliament rejected the request) The EFD Group has requested that the Commission statement on the state of the rule of law and democracy in Poland be removed from the agenda.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, my understanding is that there is an ongoing constructive dialogue between the Polish Government and the European Commission. In relation to the Constitutional Tribunal, there is no new information. Hence no steps have been taken against the Polish Government by the Commission. It sounds to me that the political rumour mill has gone into overdrive here. Let us just clarify four points: there has been no law change in relation to either women’s rights or abortion in Poland; the right to public demonstration remains as it was; there has been no law change in relation to Natura 2000; and Poland remains a member of the Istanbul Convention. This issue plainly boils down to matters of national sovereignty and I therefore request that this matter is dealt with accordingly.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! I just want to inform the House that in Poland, a large part of our public opinion is taking the idea that on 13 December and on the days when we, above all, remember a time when many of us — I do not speak figuratively at the moment, I speak literally about many of our Members — when many of us were locked up, when many of us were hiding 35 years ago, to talk about Poland in this day. I consider this conclusion to be... no, moreover, a colleague said why this conclusion is politically unfounded. But on top of that, he is still extremely inappropriate in relation to the Polish public. That is why I call for this item to be removed from the agenda.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Mr President, in reaction to the proposal regarding the developments in Poland, I have an oral compromise. There are new, serious reasons to debate the situation in Poland, but the timing is not good. This week we are coming up to the anniversary of the imposition of martial law on Polish society; it is a time to commemorate the victims and a time for reflection. Therefore, my proposal is to postpone the debate, not to Wednesday of this week, but rather to have First Vice—President Timmermans appear with his arguments in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), and to hold the debate later on the basis of this fact-finding mission.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, I must unfortunately correct the colleagues that have spoken before because there have been new developments in this very matter. After the rule of law communication that was sent by the Commission on 27 July the Polish Government handed in a response to this communication at the end of October. The Parliament has always played a very important role in this process and I do not see why we should stop now. I think that we should still be a part of this debate, have the Commission come here, give an assessment of the situation. They have not yet reacted to the letter from the Polish Government, or taken our views as parliamentarians into this whole process. I think it is our right and also our duty to be part of this process and this is why we should have the debate on the situation of rule of law and democracy in Poland this week here in Strasbourg.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr President! On behalf of the Polish delegation, I support the position of not taking this debate on 13 December, tomorrow, because 13 December marks 35 years since the introduction of martial law in Poland. Our debate on this day would cause discussions of this date, distracting attention from the essence of the state and democracy. Let this day be a time of calm reflection, what can lead too far strained conflicts, no concessions. Let this be an opportunity for us to bypass — without taking up the debate — the next tensions. There are reasons to always debate the state of law, about democracy, because that is the essence of our Union. I know the position of the Conference of Presidents; I know that the Conference of Presidents wants to propose this debate for Tuesday. I therefore formally ask, firstly, not to introduce this debate tomorrow, on 13 December. Secondly, if possible, a shift to the next session, if not, as a solution giving satisfaction to the Conference of Presidents, I propose the day after, on Wednesday 14 December.

name: Martin SCHULZ

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are calling for a statement from the Commission on Wednesday and a roll-call vote on two narcotic recommendations: the restoration of Dublin transfers and implementation of the EU-Erdogan agreement. Even the most vulnerable refugees are to be deported to Turkey and Athens is begged to rewrite laws banning it. These are law-inattentive recommendations, retransfers to Greece have been banned since 2011 by the European Court of Human Rights, then the Court of Justice and National Courts. I wonder what the method is in such madness. A Commission unable to relocate refugees, indifferent to economic misery in Greece, is posing as a power it does not have, eradicating human rights. He says refugees in Greece are better off today: there is not a single testimony to confirm this totally invented reality.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, we support this demand because we are actually dealing with recommendations that are, first of all, outrageous: to send refugees back to Greece via the Dublin procedure, which really should not happen looking at the situation and at the fact that we had delegations from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and other people going there to see the situation in the camps. Secondly, also because it is indeed a recommendation. So it is not like we can say okay, we can have a look at the legislative process and debate it later; this is actually our only chance to really bring it to the table and debate it. That is why I would ask you to support this.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Since no one wishes to speak against Mrs Spinelli's request on behalf of the GUE Group, I will put it to the vote now. (Parliament adopted the request) The EFD Group is asking for a statement by Mrs Mogherini on the attack on the Coptic Cathedral in Cairo.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, yesterday as you so rightly said, the Coptic Christian minority in Cairo were victims of a wicked attack on their Cathedral, their main place of worship. My colleague from the German delegation proposes that this House condemn the persecution of Christians and I am most happy to present this request on behalf of the EFDD Group. The European Union makes a habit of claiming to be defenders of human rights and that is why we have a duty also to defend Christian minorities and their right to worship and express their freedom of belief in areas where they are a minority. We have a moral obligation to speak up for all persecuted minorities and to condemn violence by adopting a resolution accordingly, and I urge colleagues to support me.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that we live here, like others elsewhere, in multicultural but also multifaith societies. We know that people in our societies and elsewhere are trying to set up communities, especially religious communities, against each other, and we have seen, not far from here, in the 1990s, what this notion of ethnic cleansing could produce as a horror. I therefore think it is appropriate that we have this debate.

Management of railway infrastructure by Davia-Maria Sassoli, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on a single European railway area (11199/1/2016 - C8-0426/2016 - 2013/0029 (COD)) (A8-0371/2016).

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has proposed repealing the Regulation on the regularisation of the accounting of railway undertakings, which allows Member States to reimburse railway undertakings for charges incurred by obligations incurred by other modes of transport companies do not. These obligations may apply, for example, to special charges related to accidents at work, to the pensions of railway workers who have previously retired from certain heavy work, or to the costs of level crossings. Compensation arising from those obligations is divided into fifteen different categories, whose specific scope and calculation principles are defined in the Annexes to the Regulation. The regulation was drawn up at a time when railway companies were responsible for both the operation of rail transport and the management of rail infra. At the time, the aim of the regulation was to put railway undertakings on the same line with other modes of transport, taking into account social costs and the inclusion of external costs in fares. According to the Commission, since 2007 this Regulation has been regularly used by four Member States: Belgium, Germany, Italy and Poland. Among the fifteen categories mentioned in the Regulation, payments have actually been made in only three. Parliament's first reading position was adopted on 26 February 2014. At the time, Parliament supported the repeal of the decree but required that the repeal should be delayed for two years. Following Parliament's approval of its position at first reading, the institutional negotiations were extended from October 2015 to April 2016 with the Presidents of the Council Luxembourg and the Netherlands. In early negotiations and stakeholder consultations at the second reading, we found that a transitional period is still needed for compensation for the level crossing costs — category four — because some Member States continue to use the regulation as a basis for compensation for level crossings. Member States may continue to reimburse crossing equipment costs on the basis of Article 8 of Directive 2012/34, but may still need time to change their national laws and administrative provisions. That is why, as rapporteur, my position is that the repeal of the Regulation shall comply with the Commission's proposal, with the exception of the provisions concerning the regularisation of the accounting for category four in Annex four. For category four, these provisions will continue to apply until 31 December 2017. This will allow Member States to adapt their legislation on the reimbursement of certain level crossing costs. In this context, however, I would like to emphasise that all Member States should comply with previous regulations and make no delay in transposing Directive 2012/34.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, today we are discussing a package of three closely interrelated proposals. It is an honour to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the middle section, which I have the honour to deal with, for their cooperative work today. But I would also like to draw attention to the cooperation with my colleagues Kyllönen and Sassoli to bring this package to a successful conclusion. It wasn't a simple package. Today we are talking about a further opening up of the market in the field of European rail. It is an extension of the first, second and third railway packages, and it is a next step, because there will not be a full market opening with this railway package either. In the meantime, the people of Europe also think somewhat differently about this market opening than when these proposals were written, and that is something we need to look closely at. There is a tension between the opening of the market and the public service. Many people think that public services will increase due to the opening of the market. However, we certainly do not have that guarantee, especially since there are many exceptions to the opening of the market. Member States, or at least the competent authorities, may choose from a range of exceptions in order to avoid or avoid public procurement. We have discussed all this extensively in technical consultation, and I am pleased that the national supervisors will have a greater role in this fourth railway package. This applies in particular to the exception to direct award, but also to the availability of rolling stock for the new entrepreneur entering the market. The social chapter was a difficult chapter. We have negotiated this for a long time and, in particular, with my colleague Liberadzki from the Social Democrats, we have spoken intensively. I assume that we have now struck a balance between the dynamics of the opening of the market and the protection of workers. What I have noticed in this dossier is that Directive 2001/23, which deals with the protection of workers, is being applied very moderately by the Member States, and that is an essential point for the social protection of workers. Market opening is ok, but certainly not at any price. To conclude, I would like to congratulate the Presidency of the Luxembourgers and of my own country, the Dutch, for having moved this difficult dossier smoothly after three years. That wasn't easy. I have outlined what we have done: further market opening, particularly in order to break state monopolies, protection of workers, but not marketing the case to death in the sense of absolute liberalisation. That was my input.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to immediately thank the Council and Commissioner Bulc, in particular for their active cooperation, and also the shadows of all the political groups that have given their contribution in long months of negotiation, because, after three years and two months of work, this negotiation on the fourth rail package has come to fruition, probably the most important reform rail of the European Union. There has been close cooperation between Parliament, the Commission and the Presidency, in particular the Dutch Presidency and the Luxembourg Presidency, which opened the trilogue, and all allowed them to to complete a complex path, but which went in the direction desired by Parliament. We know very well that the railway systems are very complex and the number of employees of European companies shows this: in Italy there are about 70 000, in France it is estimated about 150 000 Employees, in Germany 170 000, in Belgium there are about 30 000. So we are talking about large national companies which, of course, offer the possibility of European know-how of particular esteem. Considering the numbers, it is clear that the reform, as it was conceived, would have also caused a great deal of debate, but this is natural, especially in those countries that preferred to consolidate their own position, avoiding market openness and the consequences of competition. As I said, the scale of the reform is really historic, since it touches on all the aspects that remained uncovered in order to achieve a real liberalisation of the market. One of the most contentious points in Parliament has been on the separation between the infrastructure manager and rail enterprise. In the end, after multiple interventions on the text, Parliament and the Council shared the position that there should not be complete separation and that existing models can continue to coexist, but that is momentous put safeguards in place to ensure that infrastructure managers are impartial and can operate independently. I also recall, to clarify the philosophy of reform on a point on which incomprehensible controversy is being made, that the network remains public; network and maintenance remain public and not only for the costs impossible to incur for any private person, but as a recognition of a public good that we are committed to protecting. It is the service to go to the race instead. And linked to the structure of the railway undertaking there is a sensitive issue such as financial transparency, which is inescapable for the European Parliament. We have always reasoned at European level on the whole text and have determined that the distribution of dividends made with public money do not go to holding companies to avoid private use of funding public, but they go directly to the state. The social fallout of liberalisation, as you will understand, is remarkable; on social issues, after careful debate, proposals on the certification of cabin crew and respect were accepted the requirements on honourability for the maintenance of the railway licence. I want to stress, and I apologise if I take a few more seconds, that the text of the European Parliament has for the first time proposed a wording aimed at protecting rail workers. Of course I thank Parliament for the support it will give to the rail package and I want to thank all those who have cooperated in this reform in many months.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today’s debate marks the culmination of the really hard work and engagement of our three institutions over the course of the last five years to modernise and revitalise the rail sector. This is essential to meet our objective of smart and low-carbon transport mobility in Europe and to make rail competitive again. I would like to thank the Parliament for the support and contribution it has given on this important and highly complex legislative file. Special thanks go to the three rapporteurs, Ms Kyllönen, the Vice-President Sassoli and Mr van de Camp. Without your determination we would not be here today. Deep thanks go also to all the shadow rapporteurs and the Council presidencies of the last few years. The fourth Railway Package will complete the internal market for rail services with the opening of domestic passenger service markets. Already by 2020, all European railway undertakings will have the possibility to offer open access services throughout Europe. The principle of the competitive tendering of public service contracts in rail will also become applicable in 2023. With the new governance rules, we will provide fair rules of the game for all rail operators. Market opening is not an end but a means to boost the attractiveness of the rail sector. On the one hand, established railway companies will shape up and become more consumer-oriented in order to withstand competition from new entrants. On the other hand, a better offer of services will help the rail sector become more competitive vis-à-vis other modes of transport. The fourth Railway Package will encourage railway companies to embrace innovation. It will not only stimulate a better use of new technologies and digitalisation, but also develop innovative business models. As a consequence, existing and new railway companies can become more successful European, as well as global, players. The fourth Railway Package also means new opportunities for investment and growth of the railway sector. This will be good for EU citizens who will reap the benefits of more efficient passenger-friendly and cost-effective railways. They will have access to more and better mobility options, such as new types of multi-modality services and customer segment-specific services. More efficient railway companies can be expected to lead to lower fares for travellers, in particular on commercial lines. The Commission is aware that some of you are concerned about the possible impact of market opening on jobs and working conditions in the rail sector. Experience gained in Member States which decided to open their markets before the legal EU deadline shows that working conditions have not deteriorated. On the contrary, the wages of skilled workers, such as train drivers or traffic controllers, have increased. The fourth Railway Package will actually be good for jobs. By providing favourable conditions for the rail sector’s growth, we will secure more high-quality employment and new jobs. Because of the expected traffic growth and the current demographic trends, there is a risk of a shortage of staff in the rail sector. In this context, railway undertakings, as well as infrastructure managers and operators of rail-related services, will actually have to propose attractive working conditions to be able to recruit the necessary staff. I look forward to the forthcoming debate and thank you for your attention.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I hope to get through my speaking time vocally. First of all, we are adopting the fourth railway package this week. That is to say, there have already been three, and there was, of course, as far as the first railway package concerned, also a recast, that is, a revision. This means that we have the fifth attempt to finally get what is urgently needed, namely that the scarce resource of rail infrastructure can be used optimally across borders. I wish we could get this right now with the fourth package. I would like to remind you — and Mr van de Camp has already mentioned this — that, with the technical pillar, we have also created the technical conditions for rolling stock to be recognised across borders. So now the point is to set the organisational framework. I can only encourage everyone to confirm the agreement we have reached with the Council in the vote on Wednesday. It would be an important message at the end of this year that, after lengthy negotiations, and Commissioner has drawn attention to this — after five years — we are finally able to achieve another small gradual market opening in this area. We have to be clear about one thing: if, on the one hand, we spend money on infrastructure through the Connecting Europe Facility and through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and if we place a particular priority as the European Parliament in the rail sector, then we must also enable railway companies to be able to: to make the best use of this infrastructure in the interests of citizens.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President! Of course, the fourth rail package represents, so far, a synthesis of the transition programme in rail transport and an attempt to build a single European railway space. And as to the assumptions in this respect, we do not have any doubts anymore — after all, we want to increase the importance of railways in the transport market and in the transport of persons, and in the transport of freight. The railway is practically at the moment the only branch of transport to show such a small level of internal cohesion within the European Union. This package consists of two parts: technical and political. The technical part definitely brings facilitation, simplification, makes rail slowly similar to aviation, to the automobile manufacturing industry, and at the same time this part recognizes standards, standards. The second aspect is the political part mentioned by President Sassoli, containing an element that is called public service - public service obligations. And to that part my group has some reservations. What do these objections apply to? They concern the so-called freedom of transfer of crews between one operator who ends the concession and the new operator. We insist on ensuring the duty of taking over the crew. Why? It's about quality of service, safety. Not every cheapest solution is the best. And that's what we're going to demand.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) On behalf of the ECR, I would like to say that our group supports the fourth railway package. It's been a long breath work. We are pleased that the package is finally finished, given the benefits it brings to the traveller. For my own country, I would particularly like to draw attention to the opportunities this offers for improving the punctuality of services. The proposals introduce measurable, transparent and verifiable performance requirements for future provision of services to SNCB, the current operator of the train service. Achieving punctuality standards will therefore become more important. Hopefully, this will encourage SNCB to further transform itself into a decisive and customer-friendly company. A round of Member States has taught me that the way in which punctuality is measured is quite different in the EU. In the interests of the traveller, I think it is good that performance requirements should also be more easily comparable within the EU.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President. Commissioner, our Union needs to make the most of the potential of railways if it really wants to end congestion, decarbonise the transport sector and add competitiveness to the European economy by reducing the logistics costs of businesses and improving the mobility of goods and passengers. The adoption in this plenary of the political part of the fourth railway package has not reached what it should because of historical monopolies. We will therefore vote against the Sassoli report, supporting the amendments against the Council's agreement. The process is slow. States are slowing down. This is despite the enormous effort, which I welcome, congratulate and acknowledge, that Commissioner Bulc has made in recent years to try to get this package approved at once and end with more determination the barriers of all kinds encountered by entrepreneurship in this sector. The report on which I was working on this package, the one on common rules for the standardisation of the accounts of railway undertakings, is a symbol of how this mode of transport has worked in the Union and how we are anchored in these logics. The repeal of compensation for the construction of level crossings is delayed by two years. A new example of the shyness with which reforms are being undertaken that we should undertake with much more decisive and certification as to who we look at when we legislation in this field. The worst thing is that we're playing something as important as missing the train. And that, in this case, is much more than a rhetorical expression. That is, by being late, not deciding on time, we can miss a great opportunity to improve our quality of life and promote a quarry of quality jobs.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, services have been liberalised in Europe for 20 years with promises to create more jobs, improve the quality of the services themselves and clean-up public debts. Unfortunately the figures say exactly the opposite happened: liberalisations have produced millions of unemployed people, especially young people, worsened public accounts, since profits are privatised to socialized losses, and finally quality has lowered everywhere, because the kind of competition that has been encouraged is above all social dumping. With the fourth rail package we continue on this path, which is wrong and that is why we will vote against it. It is true, as Mr van de Camp says, that there was quite a discussion in the committees, but ultimately downside compromises were accepted and social clauses disappeared everywhere, for example the one about transferring workers, maintaining employment levels. We will vote against this fourth rail package which under the rhetoric of modernisation, liberalisation, actually hides a leap back decades on workers' rights, of quality of services, security of citizens, which is a very important fact, and also protection of disabled people. That's why we say no. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned the need to create jobs, which is very important. Concerning the Regulation on domestic passenger transport services by rail, do you not think that there is a need to strengthen the social protection in the new regulation, and that we must keep fighting for transport workers’ rights and job protection?

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: answer to a “blue card” question. — That's exactly what we intend to do, even in contact with trade unions in the category. The rights acquired were removed and Parliament, at first reading, this Parliament, had more protected workers' rights. All this has been lost in search of compromise as long as it is, and is a compromise, in our opinion, wrong.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we had a historic opportunity to improve rail transport, and we missed it. This fourth rail package is the end of a long process begun 25 years ago by the European Commission. We would have liked to have had a real European rail, a rail that is competitive in relation to road and other polluting transport, because, I recall, rail transport is the most environmentally friendly mode of transport, the least emitting CO2 and fine particulate matter. We have made no choice but to advance the share of the train in Europe, and if we want to achieve greenhouse gas reduction targets, we have not given enough resources, even though we have the Paris agreements. This aspect, which we are going to vote on Wednesday, on passenger transport is the most important, because it will be experienced directly by European citizens, in their experience as passengers, and by rail workers, who are making a leap into the unknown. On this file, we will be judged on pieces, and it is wrong to say that we will be able to revise this legislative package if it goes wrong. It's wrong! We are committed for at least twenty years, as long as all the stages of opening up to competition provided for in this package are unfolded. All this has been understood by European rail employees. They get our attention because the legislator did his job wrong, and they are afraid for their future. What was done wrong? The first thing is that the European Union has confused “liberating” and “liberalising” rail. A very easy example: in 2006, freight freight was liberalised in Europe. Ten years later, traffic fell by 30%. We liberalized without release, and the opposite effect was achieved. This example must therefore be taken in mind when passenger transport is opened up to competition. The risks that will weigh on passenger transport are of two types: first of all, the risk of deterioration in public transport. Public service networks will be opened from 2023 and the selection of the operator will be done by public procurement. There is no doubt that competition will be done by price and not on quality or high level of service. It will be expected that less safety on board, fewer services on less profitable segments, as the text gives no guarantee on these aspects. However, the solution is simple: it was necessary to impose specifications with the fullest possible mandatory European public service criteria, and that was removed from the text. We cannot vote on this text under these conditions. Another worrying example is social pricing. Other operators will not be obliged to offer social pricing. What does that mean? More low prices for students, the unemployed, people with disabilities or the elderly. We touch the very heart of the public service and our European solidarity system. Finally, for workers, it is serious what is happening: a railway agent has no guarantee that in the event of a change of operator, his employment on the network, which he is used to serve, will be preserved. We are in the process of creating a precarious profession that can be relocated with precariousness that will come back to each procurement. What do we want to show citizens? That the European Union protects them or is it precarious? So I tell you, the group of environmentalists here on Wednesday will vote against this text because it bears principles of social breakage and the breakdown of the public service. We will be alongside the employees tomorrow who will be before our European Parliament, with the hope that the other political groups, which are the majority here, will return to reason and reopen discussions. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (article 162 (8) of the Regulation)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue Card Question. — Thank you very much for the opportunity, Mr President and Mrs Congressman, for your willingness to answer. You mentioned sustainability concerns about this package and also spoke about the social dimension. It gave me a very comprehensive picture, but I would like to ask one thing: has the privatisations or opening up so far made a difference in education and training, as far as the railway professions are concerned?

name: Karima DELLI
text: answer “blue cardboard”. — We have had very concrete examples; in Germany, the Netherlands, we can see a little what happened. Today, in this fourth railway package, ladies and gentlemen, we have the opportunity to ensure that the European Union is proud of what the legislator is creating. That is, yes, sustainability, because we must finally take into account rail and train in particular, everywhere in Europe and invest. But the second thing is that we will not be able to do it without the employees. We need a new pact with employees, but also with climate targets that must be fulfilled. Without both sides, we will not succeed, and unfortunately, today neither one nor the other is up to it. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked according to the “blue card” procedure. Mr President, honourable colleague, you said that you would not vote on this report - and we are interested in the social dimension, in the social democratic group - but to me it is surprising, because it has been worked on this railway package for a very long time, and I would like to understand: if you do not vote - do you think it is better in the current situation than if we voted on this report? And I didn't understand why you're challenging the public auction, because I think the award should be done through public auction.

name: Karima DELLI
text: answer “blue card”. — Mrs Grapini, ladies and gentlemen, we are used to working together on the question of good compromises, okay? On this text you tell me: “But you do not want to move forward.” The question today is: do we want to break employees even more or protect them? I do not have the protection of employees in this text. It must be said that we do not have the protection of employees. Yet I made amendments — they were not accepted. Today, in the specifications, precisely, these criteria are not even an obligation. Everyone will do as he wants. Mrs Grapini, why am I voting against? Just because I call for your vigilance, I call for a revival of consciences in this Parliament, to say: “We cannot take this risk, so let us reopen discussions so that the so-called social and the so-called environmental best prevail above all.”

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking today on behalf of Mrs Daniela Help, who was unable to be here, but who cared for us to take part in the debate, and so I read the his message. We supported the three reports of the technical pillar, but we could not do the same for the governance part of the package, because we are disappointed at the result achieved by exposing European services risks that we have already seen in other areas, and I am thinking of the airline sector and the Alitalia case. While we are in favour of the creation of a single market and the harmonisation of the rules, we cannot forget that excessive liberalisations and without the necessary safeguards can have a negative impact on the European market. We spent on the inclusion of internal and external reciprocity clauses which, however, it was preferred not to include. We run the risk in this way that even if we demolish established state monopolies, it will open up to new public and private funds over which, however, our chances of control are considerably lower. The same applies to the protection of workers, increasingly exposed to employment risks linked to new operator changes and for which there was no thought to provide additional safeguards. For these and other reasons, we will not be able to support the reports that are being voted this week.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, the distribution of the three reports under the market part of the 4th railway package is very eloquent: a report for the moralising left, a report for the right of money and a report for the extreme left ideologist. And all of you, while you strive to oppose yourself politically, you are asking with one voice these directives which should not be called “railway package” but “rail dismantling”. For that is what it is about: an ever more advanced dismantling of the railway sector to offer it to the financial powers, on the pretext of free competition. Assumed European elites or useful naive of the globalist system, you are underway to fight global warming but encourage international journeys, when it might be more beneficial to promote proximity or the local. When it is argued that competition has allowed rail freight to advance, what I see in my country, France, is a 20 per cent collapse in rail freight in five years. Some will be satisfied with the inclusion in the competition regulation of the obligation on companies to comply with social laws and collective agreements. But still glad that companies must abide by the law! To put such ineptia on paper is proof that it has as its sole purpose the political display that will allow some of you to say to their constituents: “but we have built social protections,” when you know from experience that these pseudo-protections will remain purely theoretical. The increase in service providers will in itself result in increased fraud and social dumping, especially as regards international journeys. Do not be surprised that, year after year, betrayal after renunciation, those you call populists are becoming more and more. These are the policies that you conduct blindly, following the dogma of competition applied to the public service, which disgust citizens, who pay the high price. You do not listen to the peoples who can no longer from your ploutocratic policies. As you will understand, the MEPs of the French delegation of the ENL Group will vote against this politically hypocritical and socially disastrous reform, which will lead to the abandonment of entire regions already decommissioned, to the sole benefit of globalised metropolises. Marie-Christine Arnautu, Member of the Committee on Transport, tabled rejecting amendments for these three reports, with a roll-vote call. We will see and let us know what those who still claim to be committed to the social well-being of our fellow citizens and to the development of our regions will vote.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, as an EPP shadow on governance, first and foremost I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sassoli, for his work and his openness to cooperation during the difficult negotiations. I would also like to thank the Commission and the Dutch Presidency for their commitment and efforts in finding consensual solutions, which are sometimes very hard.  I am very happy that we have finally managed at this stage to round off the fourth railway package. I would like to welcome the fact that, despite some pressure, we have managed to deal with the political and the technical parts of the package together and that the technical documents did not become the victim of some political gains.  I think that the agreed text is a further positive step in creating a single European railway area. It will improve the quality of railway services by making them more dynamic and customer oriented. That is why the EPP Group supported all reasonable and constructive initiatives during the whole negotiation process. We have achieved a balanced text that strengthens the governance of railway infrastructure managers, prevents conflict of interests and increases the financial transparency between infrastructure managers and rail operators.  It also preserves the equal position of vertically integrated and separated company structures, and exemptions are guaranteed for special separate lines. It is time now to move forward with the implementation.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, opening up national markets, if not regulated, is not the solution. Firstly, competition is not an end in itself and is not the premise of quality of service, which must remain the main goal of public policy. Secondly, the opening of markets cannot undermine the ability of local authorities to organize and protect public services. While these two fundamental principles are found in the text, with the possibility of awarding public service contracts directly without tendering, and the possibility of limiting the arrival of private operators to protect a public service operator, on the other hand, on the social side, the account is not there. The opening of markets cannot save strong social guarantees. However, the text does not incorporate the principle of compulsory transfer of personnel in the event of a change of operator, even though this was the position of the European Parliament at first reading. I therefore call on you to vote in favour of our amendment in favour of the compulsory transfer of staff to ensure that competition is not at the expense of working conditions. Let us demonstrate that Europe protects social rights and its workers.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I would like first of all to apologise to the Commissioner as I had to leave the moment she was about to speak since I was chairing our ALDE internal working structures meeting. I am back now to make a few remarks. We most often speak across the political spectrum, across the Member States, about the need to complete the internal market. We nearly all agree on that. The moment we can complete the internal market, really integrate the markets, that’s the time we suddenly forget this political rhetoric and we find all the excuses and we really think that the national interests are those of the historic national railway companies. Well I must say one thing: if these companies are not able to compete between themselves then we can hardly expect that the railway can compete vis-à-vis other modes of transport. And I think we would all agree that the most sustainable mode of transport is the railway. We are making certain progress. I mean if I look at the PSOs I would have expected a bigger step, but it is a step and I think that we should all support it in order to comply with what are our interests, but also our responsibility vis-à-vis the focal point, and that is the consumer. One remark concerned the social standards. First of all, some of what is being said here today I have not heard in the trilogue itself nor in the shadows’ negotiations – at least from some colleagues – but I need to say that the social standards are respected. Look at the text and what it says. We fully respect the social standards and the national legislation, and in fact nobody should have any obstacle in securing, through the social standards on a national level, the quality that we want the workers to have and what we expect.  A very final remark. We have a little hypocrisy when we say that it is only the national historic companies which can secure the social standards. This is not absolutely true, and we will definitely support the PSO.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, among the objectives of the White Paper on Transport is to achieve an efficient, sustainable and cleaner transport system. The train is a good way to achieve it. And it is therefore essential that we bet on this means of transport making it accessible and useful for everyone. The fourth rail package proposes reforms necessary to achieve a better rail network, but, by any chance, the liberalisation of the railway sector is also being fenced. And it does so on the pretext that free competition will mean improving the quality of service and competitive prices. But the experience of privatization of public services is clear and demonstrates this. When the UK privatized its railroad, services deteriorated, affecting security; prices and salaries of executives of the privatized companies multiplied, some of which later broke. Total, it ended up costing the state twice as much as when it was public. In the end, the Labour Government, in the face of such a disaster, decided to renationalize it again. A public service is not for business; it is to meet a common need, which in this case is transport. If we add business profits to the railway, the result will be that the contracting companies will obtain their profits by raising prices and cutting quality of service and firing workers. And on top of that, governments like the Basque Country will let the less traveled lines die to drive the high-speed train. Final result: more car and less train. Inefficient, sustainable and polluting. (He agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: question of “blue card”. — Mr Ziluaga should know — and not distort this debate — that Renfe, in Spain, is still a public undertaking. You just stated that it was privatized. Please know before you make these statements in this House.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: answer from “blue card”. — I don't think you listened to my speech well. I never said Renfe has privatized himself. What I mean is that this fourth railway package is aimed at privatisation of the sector, as is already being done with other public services, such as health and it seems that transport is now going to be.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Mr President, in one of these packages the Commission proposes to intensify competitive pressure on domestic railway markets, then in the others it calls for more subsidisation of rail services. How can you have fair competition with more and more subsidisation? This report is full of contradictions and, as per usual, it thinks it can solve all of the EU’s rail problems with a one—size—fits—all approach which has never worked before. It concerns me that the Commission and the Chamber do not seem to learn from their mistakes. But on a positive note, being able to buy a rail ticket from my home town in Telford to Paris without having to find my way through multiple different websites and companies is fundamentally a good idea. However, this should be done on a company-to-company basis, or bilaterally for those countries with a nationalised rail service. This Chamber should be deregulating the market and enabling private enterprise to do this themselves.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner Bulc. Now, finally, we can complete the fourth railway package. After the Commission's proposals were published five years ago, it is finally time. For decades, we have been talking about the shift to rail at least — quite vain so far. It is imperative that rail become more efficient, not only more cost-effective, but simply better and more reliable. The adoption of the technical pillar in particular has already taken a major step in the right direction. The political pillar will add to this. Of course, I am not entirely satisfied with the outcome of the negotiations with the Council. With regard to rolling stock, the continuing possibility of direct awarding and long deadlines, it is simply not ambitious enough. But it's apparently the maximum we can reach right now. With regard to the takeover of staff in the event of a change of operator, I welcome the outcome of the negotiations. In the interests of subsidiarity, Member States should be able to decide for themselves. In Germany, the takeover obligation will exist. However, I am particularly pleased with our call for the introduction of common information and transit ticket systems. This is an important step towards an integrated ticket that allows multimodal and cross-border travel.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President. Yes, at last we have the political pillar which should have been the framework precisely for establishing the conditions of the technical pillar, because neither interoperability, nor security, nor even the mandate of the Railway Agency can never overcome border and nationalising obstacles and obstacles. The truth is that the Commission's mandate — and it is not you, Mrs Bulc, but rather your predecessor — on the part of the Commission should have been more innovative in business and more Europeanistic and more generous in the social sphere, rather than trying to limit itself to imposing mere liberalisation of rail transport with a restrictive approach to service obligations public. And that is the result: renationalizing and defensive on the part of the Council, and this Parliament is trying to improve it. Hence, governance is moving forward, even if we would have liked to go further. Beyond transparency; but, at least, it is moving forward in giving the possibility of introducing a vision into cross-financing between historical operators and their infrastructure operators. And, too, it advances in public service obligations, albeit with contradictions, returning to national fears, and we are much afraid that they will serve more to secure financing to operators in rich and debt-free countries, exposing more to those of indebted countries. However, we must recognize that progress has been made and that we have therefore gained some time, even if it is a smaller step than we would have wanted. But many things are clarified for the remaining tasks, which are definitively tackling the social debt, which had to be taken into account from the beginning and prepared it from the first package, in order to avoid precisely the renationalizing withdrawal that we have had. The new social pillar that is being prepared is the opportunity, Mrs Bulc, and I hope. Because the surrogacy we ask for in this fourth package we are going to vote for ports and no one will say anything; but for the railroad the shields are raised. Good thing since yesterday the trains have passed through the St. Gotthard. The Swiss did understand it. Let's see if we Europeans learn anything.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the friends of the railway, the friends of Europe, the friends of Europe, the friends of rail Europe had welcomed and supported with great enthusiasm the technical pillar of the railway package. They had also seen, with great interest, the Commission's proposal on the political pillar. The package looked like a Christmas package. Unfortunately, after the first time in Parliament, but after, above all, that all the Member States have come to committee in the Council, all getting alterations to the original text, until completely distorting it, we can say that the agreement reached with Parliament is not a compromise, it is a compromise. Moreover, in the governance directive, things are such that, from now on, we see the Member States, understanding that there is no longer a governance pillar anymore, turning back. SNCF now employs 10,000 people in its leading holding company, which is supposed to be a light administrative governance structure for two independent structures, and Renfe announced two days ago that it would reunite its infrastructure manager with its transport operator. That's the result! It's absolutely disastrous. I think that this governance directive is taking us back and not moving forward, and it is a great tragedy for Europe of rail, especially since, not only is there no opening of markets, there is a great judicial and legal instability to foresee and, as you have seen, social issues do not seem to be resolved. In short, we are not expecting a fifth rail package, since the fourth package could close the list. What I am saying is that, perhaps, it was better to give up, think a little bit, and come back a little later than arrive at a solution that ultimately will not satisfy anyone and will not open up the railway capacity further of Europe.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, faith in the market is increasingly blind. They are no longer able to justify it, they simply insist: more liberalisation which should then happen; more liberalisation, which must then happen. Looks like magic. Only reality is that she's stubborn. The process they call liberaliser is, in fact, a process of monopolistic concentration, of attacking national sovereignty, of degradation of public service and of intensifying the operation of railway workers. It is curious that they will now defend for private exploitation guarantees that have destroyed or weakened in the process of liquidation of public ownership of the railway sector, such as the greater public financing of the system, or public investment in rolling stock and infrastructure, which are necessary for ensure the profit of private people who exploit the system. Such social safeguards may serve to facilitate the collaboration of Social Democracy in this process, but in practice they are of no use as it has been made quite clear in other sectors, for example groundhandling. Finally, it is obvious that this package, as several national parliaments have said, calls into question the principle of subsidiarity and, for this reason, too, must be rejected.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, thank you to all the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs who have been involved in getting us to this position, and to the Commissioner too for her input. We are at a point now where the fourth Railway Package is to be implemented, and I welcome that because it will be good for consumers. That is why we are all here ultimately: to ensure that services provided are safe, that there is a good service, punctuality, cost and a choice of routes. I am certain that the competition that will be introduced by the opening up of the market will ensure that we do have a more dynamic rail system. Much has been said about living in a free and open market with no checks and balances in place for the private sector, and I do not believe that is the case. The strong performance criteria are going to be implemented and supervision measures – which are absolutely necessary – are going to be put in place. Ireland, along with a number of small countries, has a temporary exemption in this because the market share in Ireland is less than 0.5%, and it was perceived that there would not be any interest in opening up that market. However, performance criteria will be put in place, supervised by the National Transport Authority, and I would like to point out that the National Transport Authority is already doing that through its existing direct award contract, and that their publication of quarterly performance already covers similar indicators. We look forward to their supervision again in this area as we move forward implementing the fourth Railway Package.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: — Commissioner, fellow Members, the fourth railway package is a set of measures aimed at completing but also improving Europe's Single Transport Market, starting from removing administrative barriers for operators and ending with stimulating competition for this sector. I believe that the agreement reached is, however, a step forward, given that the realities of each Member State dictated different views on what the European rail system should look like. Overall, the political pillar we are going to vote on Wednesday has a duty to lay the foundations for a dynamic and efficient rail system, which, in the long term, can ensure the competitiveness of this mode of transport compared to that of road. Transposition of this rail package will help create a stable and more attractive legislative framework for investors. By introducing a system of auctions based on efficiency and transparency criteria, we have the chance to ensure an open environment for competition, which, in the end, I hope, will translate into better passenger services. In conclusion, however, I would like to say that work on this report will have to continue even after Wednesday's vote, the next step being to strengthen the social component by ensuring social protection and guaranteeing the rights of employees in this sector. Perhaps it would be necessary to consider a social pillar.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, it can be seen that even after three years of discussing this railway package, there are still conflicting opinions. We expect that these measures should provide a basis for the liberalisation of rail markets and ensuring access to infrastructure in all Member States for new rail carriers. Opening up the rail market to competition should increase the pressure on train companies to stand in a competitive environment and therefore also attract new investment. These measures should aim to increase the quality of services provided for consumers, reduce the price of rail services and also improve the efficiency of public financing of this sector. The separation of railway infrastructure managers from rail carriers was carried out by the Czech Republic several years ago. It really meant the approach of new companies and also the improvement of the quality of services, but I must point out, provided that there are also public and civil services in rail transport, especially on joints that are less lucrative. All these measures should lead to price cuts, savings and also, in terms of tenders, subsidised connections. But we will only manage to create a competitive environment in rail if we set the railway business in Europe a level playing field.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Unfortunately, the European Parliament's central demands at first reading cannot be found in this compromise. The fact is that, following the revision of the PSO Regulation, the call for tenders is now mandatory, with a few exceptions. The possibilities of direct public procurement will be limited and operator changes will be more frequent. The mandatory takeover of staff at the time of operator change could not be enforced, nor do minimum social requirements need to be ensured in the case of tenders. I would like to stress that these were the key demands of the Group of Socialists. What is being presented now is not a balanced compromise between market opening and social protection. The interests and protection of workers are not taken into account. On the contrary, due to personnel costs, companies participating in tenders will face down a price war. We, the SPÖ, want rail passenger transport as a public service to the general public. However, quality and efficiency are not achieved through liberalisation. Market opening can only work together with strengthening social standards and workers' rights.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Dear ladies! The adoption of the fourth rail package begins the creation of a single European rail area. Certainly, the solutions contained in this package are beneficial for consumers, because liberalisation and opening up of rail markets, the emergence of competitive players always ensure improved service quality, better carriage price, greater choice of connections, and increase the planning of supply and frequency of transport services. I also hope that there will be an increase in the amount of goods carried by rail, which will allow road transport to be offloaded. Moreover, with the implementation of the package, it will become possible to support rail investment more broadly, which will allow the new jobs needed for Europe today. Certainly, the fourth rail package represents a huge opportunity for native railways in each Member State, as they will be entitled to provide services on the internal lines of other European countries. With the introduction of the Open Tender Rule, all carriers in Europe will have access to present their offer and I know that no solution, no rights will satisfy everyone one hundred percent. Anyway, those voices, concerns about the staff were heard in this room. Nevertheless, I hope that everyone understands that the consumer is very important, that the common rail market is important for competitiveness. I would like to thank everyone who took part in creating this difficult law, because it was certainly difficult to find a consensus between expectations and opportunities.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. After more than three years, we are slowly getting to the end. I hope that this can then be successfully voted on. Our main thanks go to the European Commission for the technical dossiers that you have submitted that have actually gone in the right direction. As good as the technical dossiers were, so was your original proposal on governance, which we were then able to lead to such a good compromise thanks to the rapporteur, David Maria Sassoli. I am very surprised that there is so much support from the EPP, particularly when it comes to opening up the markets in Europe. However, it cannot be more European there. The other page finally states when it comes to workers' rights, then it should be regulated again nationally. That is why I believe that we should actually call on the PSO for what we called for at the end of the first reading in the European Parliament: namely the compulsory transfer of workers in the event of a change of operator. If this is missing, the Socialist Group will have to think again here. In this respect, I would ask you to take note of this too. Once again, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs and the Commission for the work done so far.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Mr. President, I congratulate the rapporteurs and commissioners on their great work and good reports. We want to modernise the rail sector, make it innovative, encourage the use of new technologies and new business models. The aim, of course, is to provide all our citizens with a safe, quality and cheaper rail service as possible, all of which bring market opening and greater competition. However, we must take into account the major differences in the development of railway infrastructure which is the basis for the development of transport and management services. For example, in Croatia we are waiting for large investments in railway infrastructure, and the service market could not even develop without it. Croatian railway companies do not have the same starting basis as companies in other Member States where investment in railways occurred long before. That is why I call on the European Commission and expect that Croatia will provide special business models to accelerate investment in railway infrastructure, and also develop service companies so that the strengthened can participate equally in this new model and package for rail services.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to thank the rapporteur Mr Sassoli and all the other rapporteurs for their excellent work. The adoption of the fourth rail package will allow the single European rail space to be completed, bringing to completion a process which began ten years ago, but which comes 20 years behind schedule the liberalisation of the European aviation market. So far the rail industry has never really been able to answer consumer questions, consequentially losing more and more market share. The progressive opening of the market, through the introduction of European transparency rules and the limit on the use of public financing for commercial activities will improve the performance of rail services and will offer new investment possibilities, fostering job creation. The opening of the high-speed market was an indispensable step in order to make competitive an industry which is difficult to withstand competition from other modes of transport. The greater use of European citizens to rail transport will ultimately contribute to the achievement of the European objectives on decarbonisation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — Mr President, the liberalisation of rail transport is destroying rail transport itself. The debate shows that social tariffs, support for regional railways, are being abolished. There is no full public service obligation. There is a question of the support for workers' labour rights. There are enormous concerns about the safety of the railways themselves. Successful state-owned railway undertakings are also jeopardised, and there is a risk that the control of undertakings will be passed on to a couple of companies, French or German. In Greece, the Memorandum has dissolved the Greek Railways Organization. We have staff shortages, huge problems in rolling stock, sale of TRENOSE instead of a lentil plate: EUR forty-five million to the Italian state railway company. So this is not a question of privatisation, but of renationalisation. This is the situation that unfortunately prevails on the European railways and Greece.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking all the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs — that has been a hard piece of work, we all know. The point is just that if you were to ask the citizens on the street whether we have a single market on the railways — the internal market is something that keeps us together — everyone would say: of course we have. hindered each other's access to their own national market. We are now trying to solve this with the technical package. There is also a lot of good, which has been said by others here too. In this case, the political part is all about today. As far as services are concerned, the PSO section has, in my opinion, a very good compromise between direct procurement and tenders. But as far as the other part is concerned, governance, there was a lot more in it. The Commission's original proposal was much more ambitious. I think it is a great pity that there has indeed not been a proper separation of the network and operators now and that no more competition will arise. The people would benefit from this, and so would the railways themselves. In fact, the interests of the national major railways have become more prevailed. We have competition — but we have far too little. With the integrated ticket system, you could have achieved much more. I think it's a pity that we didn't make any more.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). — (EL) Mr President, the problem with Regulation No 1192 but also with the regulations on rail transport in general is not whether the Member States can make any compensation payments to railway undertakings. The main objective of the Regulation should be to ensure a level playing field and to protect undertakings contributing to the national economies of the States. For example, there was no concern for the railway companies when illegal immigrants decided to stop rail transport at the Greek-Skopje and Greek-Bulgarian borders, causing enormous damage to the railway and transport companies. There is therefore a need for strong national public participation in conjunction with the private sector and for the implementation of a social policy for workers, with particular emphasis on the provision of adequate salaries and contributory pensions. This must be a commitment to both domestic and cross-border and transnational rail transport, in a spirit of transnational cooperation and on the basis of the principle of free movement of persons and goods.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for a very frank and dynamic debate. It clearly shows the importance you attach to the railway sector. Allow me now to reply to some of your comments and hopefully provide some clarification on what this package delivers.  First, let me clarify some of the comments that were made by Mr Liberadzki and some other Members of Parliament. On PSO, the text clarifies that all existing binding provisions at EU and Member State level remain applicable after market opening, as does their scope of application. The provisions on staff transfer of the Directive on transfer of enterprises apply to the situation of a change of freight public service contracts if the conditions of the Directive are complied with. This would essentially have to be a transfer of assets and rolling stock to the new public service operator. It is also stated that Member States can go beyond the level of staff protection, defined at EU level by Directive 2001/23/EC, for instance by requiring a transfer of staff and social rights even if Directive 2001/23/EC would not apply. Moreover, Member States are encouraged to assess the need for additional social safeguards in the case of market opening – of course in a reasonable manner. Experience shows that they do take action with mandatory measures. The new PSO Regulation also spells out more clearly the transparency requirements on social rights and obligations, where a change of public service operator contributed to better staff protection. In no way does the Fourth Railway Package lead to less social rights and protection for workers. On the contrary.  The original Commission proposals were even more ambitious, that is for sure, than what you have on your table today. I know that some of you, including all my Liberal colleagues, would have liked to go further in reforming the regulatory framework for rail, but there were also many who were not ready to take bolder steps immediately. In the negotiations, we took into account the diversity of railway systems and structures across the EU, as well as the calls for flexibility and gradual change for the benefit of a single market. The text ready for the vote is what I believe EU stakeholders can absorb and implement at this stage. However, I am also confident that we very largely shared the same ambition for the future of rail and I am convinced that when the package is implemented, it will bring the railway sector into a brighter 21st century.  Let me now make a few other comments. Rail will only be able to contribute decisively to the decarbonisation of transport – and I wish Ms Deli were still here – if it becomes more attractive, also from a service—offering point of view. This requires new investments, more efficiency and more innovation, and this is what the Fourth Railway Package is about. Other transport modes don’t sleep. They are picking up on decarbonisation and I believe in the long run, the differences will be in the amount of investments and in the amount of attractive services offered, so I hope railway will pick up on that and use this advantage, which it still has. Let me also be very clear. The package does not address the issue of railway ownership. This is a very important message. There is absolutely no obligation to privatise railway operators. What we are establishing is an equal level playing field and competitive market conditions for the benefit of our citizens and businesses. This is what the fourth railway package is about.  In the same manner, national and local authorities will still have the possibility to determine what are the needs for public service. With this package we ensure that the public services are improved and that value for taxpayers’ money is increased.  This is why I would really like to encourage you to adopt the three texts by a very large majority being approved in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and I am really looking forward to your support and positive vote and to really together make this important step forward to finally give the railways a push to be back as a full player in the single transport area arena.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I would like to thank my rapporteur colleagues and the shadow rapporteur colleagues, the committee's secretariat and the Commission and the Council's negotiating parties for their very relevant cooperation. Although this fourth rail package, as a whole, is certainly very principled for many politically, I see that the common compromise gives the Member States sufficient leeway, also allows the public service to work better, and is also in the longer term shared by all of us advantage and before all customers best. Over the past 150 years, Europe has to thank the railways for much. The sector has been in support of European industrialisation and egalitisation, according to some estimates even the generalisation of literacy, and has served as a real integrator of regions and countries, reducing the mental, physical and cultural distance between countries and between them. With good reason, you can say that rail transport in Europe is undervalued today. We therefore hope that, with this package, we will bring forward a movement that will bring a long-acting and stable regulatory framework to the European rail sector, on which it is possible to develop the sector on genuine customer terms and create a real European rail renaissance. Bringing this sector into a new flourish will fit in this time as a joint climate project for an integrated green and responsible Europe.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: rapporteur. — (NL) I would like to comment on two points. First of all, the remarks made by my Liberal colleagues, Mrs Meissner and Mr Riquet. I myself would have liked a little more ambition in the fourth railway package, and the Commissioner said that the Commission's proposals were more ambitious. I also believe that the European Parliament's first reading showed that same ambition. Then we got the trilogues and in those years something has changed. The Member States, which were initially very strong supporters of the opening of the market, scribbled back a little. I do not blame those Member States because the debate on market opening versus services in Europe has changed in recent years.
