Then you can push on about that, but it's good to implement what we have now and look further. The second point concerns the social component. I fully understand the concerns of colleagues in the S&D Group, but on the other hand, we must also be honest. There are national regulations, there is subsidiarity and there are the guarantees given by the European Commission. Moreover, as research shows, the companies that have been privatised have, in general, certainly not received worse working conditions after privatisation. I said it in my first speaking time: we need to strike a balance between social protection, movement and innovation. I think we've found that balance.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to all the Members who have spoken, including those who have criticised certain aspects of the reform. I must say, however, that it is truly a bit unbelievable, I say this with sympathy, that after three years and two months of work and seven months of trilogue, we come to this House to argue that the fourth package incites privatization: this I have to say is a bit unbearable. I am sorry that there are no colleagues who have spoken on this, because, I am also telling the public, no national or European union initials have ever claimed that the fourth package should lead to the privatization. There are comments, for example, on the transfer, as the rapporteur, Mr van de Camp knows very well, but we are not talking about processes that lead to privatising anything. Let's talk about opening the market, liberalizing services and, say it at home, here network and maintenance will remain public. That's the philosophy and outline of this fourth package. We will open the market from 2019, that is why some observations, such as the one made by Mr D'Amato, are, let us say, be out of place, because reciprocity would have been there in a transitional period, but since we decided to open from 2019, until 2019 everyone behaves as they decided to behave. Then as for Mr Bilbao, who graciously and diligently followed the whole debate, we are the question of unbundling — because your criticism, the criticism of the Liberal Democrats is on this aspect — we discussed it, but indeed the economic incompatibility was really great. And then what have we done, we have given powers to national regulators and the novelty aspect of the fourth package compared to the previous one is precisely the power of national regulators, their centrality in the system and that should make you say it's a step forward, it certainly isn't a step back or remain firm, as Mr Riquet knows very well, who has followed all our work with great expertise, willingness and with great experience. I would like to say, President, and I would like to thank everyone who has intervened, really, because we have a great chance, and I apologize for the time taken. We have the possibility that our companies in a European market will give jobs, work, not take off jobs, because we need to make sure that our companies participate in a more market great, because our companies, even the strongest ones, in their domestic and domestic market can't take it anymore. That is why this reform is important and why it opens up great possibilities for the European rail sector.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - The application of two out of four European freedoms, the free movement of persons and goods, is not possible without a functional infrastructure and the removal of existing barriers. Railways have played their historical role in connecting Europe, but their importance will not decrease in the future, but will increase. As this is the most ecological and efficient way of transporting long distances on land, the European Union wants to strengthen rail transport and prepare it for an era of automation and digitisation. Reconciliation of different technical regulations, certificates for train staff and increased transparency in selection processes are the first steps towards creating a single rail transport system across Europe that will be built on the competitiveness of different carriers, thereby increasing the pressure on quality and will reduce prices for both people and companies.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Knut Fleckenstein, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework on market access in port services and financial transparency in ports (COM (2013) 0296 - C7-0144/2013 - 2013/0157 (COD) (A8-0023/2016).

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Never ending stories sometimes end. After 15 years — and the last three and a half years with me as rapporteur — we are now being presented an acceptable result for port regulation. Resistance from ports, terminal operators, pilots, dockers and their unions has paid off. We were able to prevent: the forced liberalisation of port services, the introduction of self-handling of ships, the extension of the concession directive through the back door and a lot of unnecessary bureaucracy. To this end, we have jointly developed a flexible framework for ports, which also takes into account their differences. We have created more financial transparency when it comes to public financial support. And found an unbureaucratic approach that improves the position of port users vis-à-vis port operators and stakeholders, with a supervisory authority that deals with complaints adequately and seriously. We have been able to strengthen workers' rights, incorporated the right to strike and emphasised the importance of education and training. The competitiveness of ports also depends on good jobs and on well-trained dockers. Not everything could be realized according to our ideas. We would have liked to have given aid greater autonomy. However, in addition to the result now before us, the European Council was not prepared to do so. Too bad we could have seize the opportunity. I would like to comment on three points that are important to me in connection with the Port Regulation. Firstly, I enshrined training and training in the regulation because I learned firsthand during my visits to European ports that there are some subcontractors who do not have to apply any training and training rules. It's good that which is also taken into account in our text. That is why we also believe that liberalisation of training is not the right way and would seriously jeopardise safety in the port. Secondly, in the regulation we call on the Commission to clarify when public infrastructure — particularly in access infrastructures — does not meet the state aid situation in the first place. The Commission as a whole seems to have also recognised the importance of access infrastructures, otherwise it would not have included them in the analysis grids, for example. But then, please also in communication, where, according to the Commission itself, it belongs! We therefore call for a revision of the notice on the concept of aid, as it is officially called. If the Commission already refuses the recital to the GBER — that is, the block exemptions. Thirdly, we were able to prevent the extension of the concession directive through the back door in the port regulations. It cannot be that the Commission — not please, Commissioner, but your colleagues — now seems to be trying to run the whole game through the GBER. That is why we are going to tell you today that with the adoption of port regulation, the issue has not been settled for us. Last point: we all have the same goal. Strengthening the competitiveness of ports, and for this we need good working conditions and a stable and coherent legal framework and planning security for both public and private investors. I would like to thank all the parties involved, in particular ESPO and the terminal operators, including the trade unions. Without their support and goodwill to succeed, we would not have come that far. Thank you all.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I really wish to thank the Parliament and its rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, as well as the shadow rapporteurs in the Committee on Transport and Tourism for the important work they have accomplished. The Commission welcomes the agreement reached in the trilogue – 15 years is a really long time. Maritime ports are vital for the European economy, for an efficient internal market, and to connect Europe to the world. With their logistic and industrial activities, maritime ports provide employment to three million Europeans. They are also critical for developing short-sea shipping as an alternative to road transport as part of our strategy to decarbonise transport. This is why maritime ports are extremely valuable assets to be preserved and strengthened. That is what we will achieve with the regulation discussed today, and that is why the Commission considers this file a priority under the work programme for 2016. First, the regulation will ensure greater transparency for the use of public funds in ports. Many receive considerable financial support from both national and EU budgets. Transparency will contribute to a genuine level playing field between European ports. It will also help to make public funding more efficient. The Court of Auditors stressed the need to address this issue in a recent report. Second, the regulation creates a common framework for the provision of port services. This framework brings legal stability for the tendering of port services. It will end today’s unclear situation where port policy is not decided by you, the legislators, but rather by judgments of the European Court of Justice on a case-by-case basis. Third, it will ensure better training of port workers in line with the work undertaken by the social partners. Finally, the regulation will contribute to our decarbonisation strategy. We need to green the shipping industry and promote short-sea shipping. This requires investment and the right type of investment in ports, and investments need transparency. Many of you attach great importance to clear and simple state aid rules. The Commission shares this attachment. We have been working a lot on the issue of state aid in ports over the last months. My colleague, Commissioner Vestager, and I are making sure that the views of European ports are adequately taken into account. Replying last week to a parliamentary question from Mr Fleckenstein the Commission clarified the framework for state aid in ports, including the general block exemption regulation. The situation is as follows. A new set of infrastructure analytical grids was published on 2 December 2016. With this document, the Commission explains which infrastructures are considered to be non—economic and which should therefore not fall under the state aid rules. This infrastructure includes defence infrastructure, such as dykes, and access infrastructure to ports, such as a river flowing through the port that can be used by anyone. Last week, the Commission also completed its second public consultation on the General Block Exemption Regulation. Its objective is to identify which public investments in port infrastructure are considered state aid, but which are unproblematic and therefore do not need to be notified. We are now analysing the replies to improve the text further and adopt the regulation in 2017. The result of the analytical grid and a revised General Block Exemption Regulation will be more legal certainty and more clarity. But there will be no change in the decision-making practice of the Commission. With this work we are doing exactly what you have been calling for under recital 45 of the port services regulation. However, for institutional reasons and to recall the better law-making principles agreed between the Commission and the co-legislators, we will record a statement from the Commission regarding this recital. The text is balanced. It is the result of three years of discussion with all the stakeholders. All major organisations representing the European port sector stand behind it; the trade unions, port authorities, port terminal operators and port service providers. It received a strong support in the Transport Committee and was accepted unanimously by Member States. So now it is time to conclude the legislative procedure in first reading. All the circumstances allow it.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (EL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you referred to the fifteen years of hard work on this piece of legislation, and I also refer to the last two and a half, which, as shadow rapporteur, I have tried to contribute to the creation of this piece of legislation on the the free organisation of port services, which undoubtedly enhance transparency in port financing and high-quality services. It is important that we have reached a substantial agreement with the Council through intensive efforts. It should be clarified that this legislation does not impose a specific model of service management, because port authorities remain independent and thus reinforces competition. The regulations provide for the limitation of the number of service providers, the possibility of public service and provisions providing for the control of the avoidance of disproportionate administrative burdens and additional costs for small ports. Also, the new regulation has to be said that it provides fair conditions of competition, specific rules of transparency and legal certainty and a stable legal framework, which does not have disproportionate contradictory interpretations, and thus strengthens investment. You will allow me to make a special mention of my country of Greece, which is a long naval tradition. My country can benefit from this, because this new system of rules, which includes twenty-five ports, strengthens the performance of port services, creates an attractive environment for investment and, above all, contributes to economic growth which is so much needed. my country today. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue Card question. — Madam Honourable Member, You, as one of the shadow rapporteurs of this report, are obviously biased in relation to the report, but as we discussed in the previous subject, in the railway package, one of the regrettable features of these framework agreements is that training and education always goes somewhere in the background. I ask: are you satisfied with what this draft provides for training and education?

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), answer to a blue-card question. — Mr President, I would like to tell you that the maximum effort has been made in the text on the particular issue you are referring to, because ensuring a legislative framework which cannot be interpreted differently also ensures that the education, so that those who are part of the provision of services can really ensure an environment that investors find attractive, so that they can contribute to the economy where this legislative framework is mentioned.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Dear Fellow Rapporteur! He has already sounded a two-headed note in this room: the balanced approach of the rapporteur, which he has shown on the weak points, which he has shown on matters that seem still at least worth taking and the enthusiasm of the shadow rapporteur, as well as the Commissioner, such a liberal-chadecki enthusiasm that is all great. In my constituency there are the ports of Szczecin and Świnoujście, right next to Gdańsk and Gdynia, and they do not support it, neither do unionists from these ports. Because here we have a breakdown — what you're proposing is certainly good for great strong ports, and it's not necessarily good for ports that are still in the growing stages. We would like the port infrastructure to be treated like rail or road, that is, there has to be state aid, we need to create sea-land transport chains, that must serve to raise the level of cohesion of our continent. Therefore, transparency as such is obviously needed, but let's remember: liberalisation is not the goal, liberalisation can be a means to make these ports work well, because they work perfectly well. By contrast, the Court of Auditors points to a waste of money spent on investments. Why? Because no harmonization, and this package doesn't quite guarantee it.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, first of all warm compliments to Mr Fleckenstein for all his work. 2001, 2004: so far, the proposal for a new European port regulation has fallen. In my view, this was mainly due to the 'one size fits all' approach that the European Commission has always advocated. But Europe and its ports are very diverse, and we have taken that into account in the proposal we have now before us. Because the proposal that the Commission came up with the third time still largely boils down to that 'one size fits all' approach. However, we have been able to make sufficient adjustments, making this proposal good for Europe, good for the Netherlands and good for ports such as Rotterdam. What have we improved? In the original Commission proposal, ports were to be opened to a whole range of service providers: rowers, dredgers, sheds. That is quite conceived, but it must also be able to work in practice. Some ports, for example, are too small to allow all this. Safety must not be comminded either, so multiple piloting services in one port are not always sensible. As a result of our modifications, there are now all kinds of possibilities for exceptions and, for example, a port like Rotterdam can now go on with a single pilotage service and also has control over who can and cannot work in the port. At the same time, we have ensured that there are not too much administrative burdens. For example, the Commission proposed that the port authority should provide workers in the ports with relevant training and training. Yes, that is a nice idea, but many ports in my country, for example, are not about that at all. So we removed that and a comprehensive set of requirements for independent supervision has been reduced to realistic and reasonable proportions. One last, very important point is that the provisions on financial transparency have improved and have remained upright. Ports must continue to open up their finances, which is crucial for a level playing field. We do not want Member States under the table financially benefitting from their own ports. So I support this amended proposal.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank Knut Fleckenstein. I have to say that we have come to an end with the port package — similar to the railway package — a very long history, or can finish it today. With the port package, however, it was different from the railways. We were quite unanimous in Parliament from the outset. First of all, we agreed that we did not need a port package at all, because everything is actually working well with the ports. A few things could be improved, but we all fought back at first. We have now received the package from the Commission. In our opinion, there were sometimes too many regulations in place that just went more in the direction of one size fits all. Peter van Dalen just said it, but that doesn't quite fit. Ports are very diverse, have very different circumstances in terms of natural conditions and also in terms of economic positioning. I guess — we agreed on that too — what works, you shouldn't completely change that. It is, of course, important that some things have already been improved and, in general, the European rules should be laid down differently and better harmonised. That was the case, for example: we now have more transparency in finances — that's good. We have more legal certainty for investors, which is also good. Then the investors come and do something in the ports. We have more clarity in the calls for tenders, which is also very reasonable. We therefore have better conditions for competition. The fact is that Port Package 3 has actually finished, the predecessors did not make it to the vote — so they really could be signed and finished in the trilogue. The ports need planning security and need a few rules of the game that are similarly observed everywhere , and you have now. But it has been made so flexible, Knut Fleckenstein has said that there are indeed basic conditions in which everyone can exist well in their diversity. I think that's a very important thing. In some cases, we Liberals would have wished for even more competition and fewer exceptions. There are some things that have been taken out. One exception, which I like, is that a captain, if he is very experienced, can operate at certain ports without pilots. This is one thing you just need, because those who have been driving certain routes for a long time can do it alone. Not in major ports like Rotterdam, of course, but many other ports give it up. Finally, it has been said that the subject of the Block Exemption Regulation is not quite complete. Knut Fleckenstein said that we must ensure that, for example, a port which, due to natural conditions, has to dredge more than another, does not get a competitive disadvantage.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet the motion of the rapporteur Fleckenstein and hope that the regulation will win the support of Parliament in Wednesday's vote. The negotiations on this regulation have been very long and very tough and I am pleased that Parliament and the Council finally reached agreement. This regulation will hopefully clarify the open issues surrounding port funding transparency, governance models and, among other things, the status of workers and training opportunities. The regulation leaves the Member States with sufficient leeway to take account of national features, and it is time to move this forward so that we can focus on promoting sustainable and efficient maritime transport. We are facing a number of carbon dioxide reductions in shipping and decisions on maritime propulsion. The EU is gratifyingly unanimous, but the movement would like to be more vigil at international level. I therefore hope that good and close cooperation, both within Parliament and between EU institutions, will continue on these themes.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the regulation on port services shows how difficult it is to develop a policy that works well for the many and varied ports we have across our continent. From the perspective of the UK, where ports have been run as private businesses for many years, many of the concerns of the Committee on Transport and Tourism are simply not relevant, and the need for greater financial transparency for the smaller ports in southern Member States has much less salience in the case of the larger ports of northern Europe. We have sought greater clarity over state aid regulations so that public money given to European ports does not distort competition between them. As for the liberalisation of port services, perhaps we should apply the principle of subsidiarity, leaving countries free to choose whether or not they run ports as part of the public infrastructure.  As Greens, we also sought to have environmental criteria when setting charges for port services and were sorry to see this removed. Worse still, the references we had added to the need to ensure strict adherence to EU law to protect the environment were also removed. A glimmer of hope can be found in the support for the use of short—sea shipping and inland waterways and railways for the delivery of goods, reducing the need for long distance road freight and the traffic congestion and unnecessary emissions it causes. But overall I have to say that we are disappointed in this proposal and consider that an opportunity to reduce the negative environmental impact of Europe’s ports has been missed.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this proposal for market access, support services and financial transparency does nothing for ports in the United Kingdom. The port sector in the UK is the second largest in the European Union and all the ports represented by the UKMPG and BPA already operate within a competitive independent market-driven sector, providing wide choice to users. This regulation will have a significant impact on privately—financed ports by preventing them from operating as fully commercial businesses. This will threaten essential future investment and put people’s jobs at risk. It is not clear how this legislation will add any value. The United Kingdom is leaving the EU and regulation like this is typical of the reasons why. We do not need this speculation. We do not want this regulation; yet it will become a requirement in the UK if passed by the EU.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, although there are minor changes to the text, I deeply regret that this proposal has returned to this Chamber. Having been in contact with local ports recently – as recently as last week – I am in no doubt that this regulation would be bad for jobs and bad for Northern Ireland. Yet again, the EU wants to take what is good and successful about an industry and enforce a ‘one size fits all’ approach. Ports in Northern Ireland are already part of a private, thriving and independent UK sector. Belfast Harbour handles goods valued at 30 billion annually, with 700 companies based in the harbour estate, employing over 22 000 people. The new changes will create barriers through excessive regulation, oversight and administration. This proposal simply means  more of the same, so I am thankful that the British people have voted to break free of this type of bureaucracy and  would call upon UK ministers to respect their wishes and make opting out of the regulation a key priority in exit negotiations.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: — Before we know it, 12 December 2016 will be another historic day because we are finalising both the Fourth Railway Package and the Port Regulation! I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for all the work he has done, because it was not an easy job. My colleague Peter van Dalen has already indicated quite well what elements we have deleted and changed, and Mrs Vozemberg has also done her job as a Greek MEP. We must pay particular attention to the issue of state aid. Mr Fleckenstein has always tried to tell Mrs Bulc's colleagues what we should now understand by this state aid. It is not clear yet, but I understand that we have a further explanation from Mrs Bulc's colleagues. In the meantime, these ports are actually doing quite well, and I would also like to draw attention to the element of training. We see a shortage of staff in the maritime sector, both in inland shipping and at sea, and good training is a prerequisite. I think we're making a good move today and thank you very much.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the adoption of this regulation in plenary represents a goal that is nothing at all discounted. As we well know, previous approval attempts have failed, a sign that this matter is really complex and delicate and requires great care and prudence. 1 200 European seaports do transit more than 70% of imported and exported goods and account for almost 40% of trade within the European Union. That is why the vote in favour of the agreement reached, the result of our parliamentary work with the contribution of all the stakeholders, is even more important. I would like to thank the rapporteur, as well as for his determination, for accepting my request for greater transparency also on customs services: full competition and competitiveness between ports cannot be irrespective of by this factor. I also believe that the legislative choice of the regulation was decisive, because in order to have a real incisiveness it is necessary to have equal rules for all Member States, which are immediately Applicable, and you need to enjoy some flexibility to achieve the end commensurate with the needs of the individual port. Thanks to these factors of financial transparency, liberalisation of services and incentive to competitiveness, sea transport will be able to grow for the benefit not only of trade, but also of the its sustainability.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. President, too many initiatives came from this House that aimed to establish costly universal governance models that were needlessly hitting European diversity and seeking to replace existing national models. This report does exactly the opposite and I have to welcome that. The Rapporteur respects the diversity of port and port service management models within the European Union and refuses to establish a single system. If something works well, it does not need to be repaired. I also welcome the insistence on competition, but I must express my concern by prescribing minimum requirements for the provision of port services. Of course our goal is that the services are provided by competent and reliable companies, but we must make sure that the required minimum conditions are not too strict, because we will leave space only for the largest companies. In this way, we would create an oligopoly and achieve effects contrary to those that the rapporteur and all of us want together.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with more than 1 200 ports in Europe, port activities represent 3 million jobs. 96 percent of freight and 93 percent of passengers transit through 319 ports in the TEN-T network. In this context, Mr Fleckenstein's proposal for a regulation is included, although quite easing from the Commission's initial objectives. We do not share the full liberalisation of port services, given the inevitable negative consequences on such an uneven sector in Europe, but the regulation still represents a step forward. Collective actions are not deemed disruptions to services justifying emergency measures; both the right to strike and minimum services are protected. The reference to the 2001 Directive reaffirms the rights of workers in the event of company transfer, as well as the obligations of originators and assignees. Training rights and the provision of minimum professional requirements ensure the safety and good execution of services. Finally, transparency on the use of public funds, achieved with a clear separation in budgets between public and private funds, will allow you to track the use of taxpayers” money and understand the activities to which are intended.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). — Mr President, the European Union always finds ways, using fine words and expressions, to conceal the true purpose of its actions. This report could not be an exception. You are trying once again to control the economic and commercial activities of the Member States, with the ultimate aim of serving specific economic interests with which some may maintain excellent relations. As far as workers are concerned, it has been shown that, in its recent history, the Union is systematically undermining their rights and conquests by wrong actions and decisions. Europe's ports belong to the states of Europe, and only they should control their exploitation. There are many reasons, and they are not only economic, especially with regard to Greece. We must not forget that port management is primarily a matter of national security, especially when the insane Erdogan is your neighbour. Finally, we have seen from the privatisation of the port of Piraeus where neoliberal practices lead and what future they have for workers: only poverty and despair uncertainty.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Ports are one of the most important elements of the global supply chain and are crucial for the European transport sector and the competitiveness of our continent. Therefore, it is so important to adopt solutions that improve rather than reduce the operation of ports, while taking into account the specificity of port management in each Member State, the specific hydrological and ecological conditions of marine areas. I am pleased that you have been able to convince your rapporteur that often approach and action at national level is better than actions at European level. I am pleased that dredging, pilot work has been excluded from the report, giving the opportunity to offer them on the basis of national law. It is important that the final version of the regulation, as well as the compromise negotiated in the Council, provides for the existence of different organizational models, as well as the preservation of the autonomy of port boards in the areas of fixing port fees, but at the same time draws attention to greater financial transparency. Please, sir! Fifteen years of work on this matter, on this dossier, shows how difficult and how fragile this tissue is. I am very pleased that the President and everyone who worked on this report took into account the many comments that came from the Member States and also the many amendments that we made throughout the work.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, Mr Czarnecki, you have a better accent every day, I acknowledge that. We are here in the face of this port package which, again, has come up with a purely liberalizing proposal without any serious social counterpart. And that comes at a price, since we have barely managed to make progress in European harmonisation. I was satisfied until this debate because, for the first time, we had achieved — thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein — greater transparency in the financial flows between public authorities and ports in order to precisely avoid unfair competition, precisely, hidden State aid. But from the news you have just given us — perhaps I misunderstood — I have to protest strongly, because I see clearly that we have tried to use this regulation — which has become something else — to negotiate in parallel. Legitimate negotiation of the rapporteur, but which is really unfair with the ports of countries in difficulty and which certainly favours the two major ports, which are already so megaports that at some point they will have to be divided. And therefore, we demand the Commission not to give in to these siren songs. Mrs. Bulc, what will happen to your port in Koper, not to say mine in Valencia, Malaga or Barcelona? In other words, the Regulation on State aid to southern ports cannot be discriminated against in relation to northern ports. On the other hand, however, I must acknowledge our satisfaction, because we have been able to exclude from the totum revolutum port practices, which continue to provide an essential public service in the areas of safety and security, environmental protection and even early warning on ships where illegal matters occur. social and the crew is exploited. We have also achieved a rather presentable surrogacy clause and improvements in training. And finally, Spanish socialists have recognized our peculiarity for the solidarity network of Spanish ports.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Mr President, as MEP of a region with four very successful privatised ports – Hull, Immingham, Goole and Grimsby – I am very disappointed with this regulation. It will impose costly administration on private ports without bringing any added value to them. Its failure to tackle the problem of state aid, as well as all the loopholes inside it, means that it simply will not open up port services to competition.  As has been shown in the Member States which have privatised port sectors, it is competition between ports rather than prescriptive regulation that delivers greater efficiency. As a spokesman on SMEs, I am particularly disappointed that exemptions for smaller ports were removed. It does seem that the Commission has succeeded with its ‘third-time-lucky’ approach here. What a shame it comes at the expense of the port industries of Europe.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! European shipping is one of our major export occupations, which creates growth and jobs, and so does it in our ports. European ports are important in a coherent transport and logistics chain, but there are also a need for administrative simplifications here. We also need transparency in public funding so that we can have an equal and fair competition the ports between. Then we get more assurance that competition rules are being complied with. I would like to think we had been a bit more concrete in this area, but now we have to see the time to see how this is going to end. It will not be very long before we are about to vote in the plenary session on the ETS (emissions trading scheme) for shipping companies. So this will also have an impact for our ports, and I hope we find the IMO track, rather than we want to legislate even here in the European Parliament, where we will also have an impact on European ports. If this is the case that, in future, transport from third countries will go to UK and North Africa to avoid the ETs, the expensive bill, then there is no doubt that it will also have an effect on our ports. I therefore hope that we can get a solution so that we do not skew activities at European ports rather than ports just outside Europe, but it is then a decision we will take next time.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Mr President! The port package has theoretically correct assumptions as it envisages an increase in competition in the services market. The most important, however, is not competition for the ports of European countries, only competition between them and other ports, including on other continents. Maritime transport is world-wide and there cannot be too much financial or administrative burden imposed on ports in Europe. If we do, then European ports in competition around the world could lose out, and together with ports, shipowners and shipbuilding will lose. I would therefore urge that we look at European ports in such a way and not just what is happening inside the Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all colleagues who have made improvements to this regulation. As shown in the explanatory memorandum, Europe is the region with the highest port density in the world. Effective trade also depends on the port network, which is why I consider this regulation important, and I support it. Sure, it's not perfect. My country also has a large number of ports on the Danube and the Black Sea, which are smaller, larger, and, I think, there is a need to optimise port activity, because unfortunately, not all seaports - the more than twelve thousand in Europe - offer high-level services. Often, the current framework of port governance is not always attractive enough for investors. That is why I agree with the amendments made by the rapporteur and colleagues and believe that the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality are respected, and I also appreciate in the report that it is foreseen that the procedure for selecting service providers should be open to all parties interested, non-discriminatory and transparent. It is very good that the system of charges for the use of port infrastructure, defined by the port managing body and, of course, the training that has been discussed, has also been clarified. I therefore support this report and congratulate the Commission and colleagues who have made amendments to the regulation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I also appreciate the strengthening of legal transparency in this new proposal for a regulation, of course the effort to better harmonise, there are a number of small improvements that can be welcome. I also welcome that the agreement over this port package is greater than in the previous case, in the case of the rail package. However, there are some risks. I'm not quite sure if the principle of subsidiarity has been followed. Indeed, it is a fact that today there is already a great deal of competition between ports. Won't that competitiveness be compromised by this package? This is only a question and I think the Commissioner should respond to this because such a reminder has been repeated in the discussion. For me it is important that we will try to encourage investment in ports, undoubtedly our seaports are access to our internal markets, but we should not limit them unprepared by legislation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the new regulation on access to the market for port services will make European ports more efficient and will provide fair competition in a sector which in Europe employs three million people. The strengthening of the competitiveness of the ports will create the conditions to promote short-haul shipping as an alternative to that by road, resulting in a reduction in costs for users. Important is the introduction of general rules for greater financial transparency of ports, legislation so far given to individual Member States. The reform will make the burdens for services and port infrastructure more transparent, especially in financial relations between the state, ports and operators. It should be emphasized that there are some important derogations, such as drainage services, and some flexibility, such as in the case of piloting services, but the introduction of greater transparency, regulatory simplification, the opening of markets and internationalisation in an intermodal European framework within the framework of TEN-T can really be a flywheel for recovery and economic growth of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: (ECR). — (EL) Mr President, port activities contribute directly to employment, to attracting investment and to GDP growth, so it is important to have transparency in the financial relations of public authorities, port authorities and port service providers so that create a level playing field and, of course, attract investment. However, transparency in port activities should not be the sole objective of the Union. There should be an increase in the European Union's funding expenditure to support ports and maritime transport. At the same time, especially in Greece, to block the sale of strategic infrastructure instead of a lentil plate, such as the sale of the port of Piraeus to COSCO, the launching of the sale of the Thessaloniki Port Authority and other ports. At the moment, all infrastructure in Greece is being divested instead of a lentil plate. Valid for airports, valid for ports, valid for railways. This unacceptable situation in my country cannot continue.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, the conversation is neither new nor the original arguments. Under the cover of a myrific modernization of services and operations, the liberalization and privatization of another strategic sector of the economy is the port sector. The promises have already been seen in other sectors: to capture investment, greater efficiency, better quality, we know what all this means. It is true that this proposal falls far short of what were the initial liberalising ambitions of the European Commission. It reduces the degree of liberalisation, a retreat which is certainly forced by the struggle, by the resistance of the workers in the first place and which we value here. But the fact is that, despite this, the proposal does not fail to point out a path, a negative path and which must be tackled. The concern expressed with regard to port users is amusing. It is funny that, while in other sectors users become customers, for example in the case of public transport, where customers are large companies, then we are already talking about users. Very clear and very clear from the point of view expressed here, that of big business, that of large economic groups, that of large multinationals.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Mr President, I would like to say that there are undeniable improvements in this regulation. Removing restrictions on the provision of port services and increasing transparency in port financing is laudable. Commissioner, I do not agree with the further liberalisation of the European port system, I think it is working reasonably well. I therefore welcome the changes in this negotiation. But I do want to tell you, as my colleague, Mrs Ayala said, that I am concerned that in her speech she has announced a possible regulation on the exemption of State aid in ports. I think that, if that is the case, it creates great discrimination in favour of resource-intensive countries, as is the case in the north, which mainly favours two ports in the European North and harms the rest. I think this should be clarified now, in your second speech.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I am speaking tonight in support of this report. I very much want to thank our rapporteur, Knut Fleckenstein, for the amazing work he has done on the report; it really has not been easy. The reason that we have had a good result is because we had a very detailed debate on this back in March, at first reading, and I do think that there is a balanced result.  I know that UK ports still have some concerns, but, with proper implementation and good interpretation, the rules on transparency can work to the benefit of everyone. Also, I particularly welcome the specific reinforcement in the text of training rights for workers, and also the social dialogue: the importance of dialogue between trade unions and workers at European level and other levels.  Finally, to the Commission: please, as other speakers have also said, take this regulation and do not seek to come back in a couple of years time to mandate more market access. This is not what we need in this sector; it is vital for our economy across Europe and it is vital for the many, many thousands of workers who work in this sector.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for the debate. I have listened very carefully to what you have said, so allow me now to address a couple of your concerns and comments. First, the regulation does not impose a one-size-fits-all approach. We know that every port in Europe is different. The regulation respects this, including the public or private ownership of ports. It is really important to know that this regulation applies only to the ports of European interest, which were identified as such in the trans-European network by the European Parliament and the Council in 2013. This refers to 329 ports out of 1200 ports in Europe. This is a very important message that needs to be taken on board. The regulation also includes tailor-made provisions to avoid putting unnecessary burdens on the smaller ports in the trans-European network with a more local dimension. Second, on the point of private ports which do not receive public funds, let me stress that they do not have to apply the rules on financial transparency, and this has to be very clear. I would greatly appreciate if you can pass this message on clearly. However, private ports as private undertakings should apply the same rules on the provision of port services, including ensuring adequate training. On the other hand, we see no good reason to allow a private undertaking to potentially abuse its dominant position vis-à-vis others on the mere grounds that it is private. So let me add to this two more comments on social aspects: firstly, the regulation will improve the training of the employees of the port service providers; secondly, it respects the tradition and ongoing social dialogue in each Member State. It allows – but does not impose – the transfer of the rights of workers from one undertaking to the new one in case of change of contracts. The discussion shows that the agreement of the trilogue between Council and the Transport Committee strikes the right balance. As regards state aid the process is ongoing. I can reassure you that the Commission will do as much as it can within its remit to integrate the latest comments made by the Parliament and the interested parties, notably in the final version of the General Block Exemption Regulation. Maritime ports are vital for the competitiveness of the Union and sustainable multi-modal transport. So that is why the EU is providing a substantial part of its Connecting Europe Facility budget to support infrastructure investments in ports belonging to our TEN-T corridors – EUR 760 million since 2014 – or in infrastructure connecting those ports, railways, for example. The Port Services Regulation will ensure that investors are adequately consulted. The momentum is there to create a European framework which provides a level playing field and creates legal stability for investors, port workers and users. So at the end, let me just wrap up. The Port Services Regulation creates a stable framework in which ports will be able to: first, develop; second, attract private investors; third, improve their public spending; fourth, improve the quality of port services; and finally, contribute to more efficient logistic chains and sustainable transport. Commission statement on recital 45 of the Proposal for a Regulation establishing a framework on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports The Commission considers that recital 45 should not have been included for the following reasons. First, the recital does not relate to any of the enacting terms of the regulation and hence does not comply with the principles of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. In that agreement, the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission confirmed that they remain fully committed to the Interinstitutional agreement on common guidelines for the quality of drafting of Community legislation, which provides that the purpose of recitals is to set out concise reasons for the chief provisions of the enacting terms, without reproducing or paraphrasing them, and that recitals should not contain normative provisions or political exhortations. Second, the Commission recalls that the notion of State aid within the meaning of Article 107(1) TFEU is an objective one, enshrined in the Treaty and not at the disposal of the Union legislator. It can only be applied as such by the Commission or national courts in specific cases, subject to the control of the Union courts. Third, the wording of the recital may create confusion. Having regard to the Treaty notion of State aid, it cannot be claimed that public funding of all access and defence infrastructure accessible to all users on equal and non-discriminatory terms always falls outside the scope of the State aid rules. The Commission's decisional practice shows, for instance, that public funding of certain access infrastructure located within the area of a port may constitute State aid.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President. I don't want to go into all the things that have been said here. The Commissioner has already explained many things very clearly. Mr. Marias! The privatisation of Greek infrastructure is, in my opinion, a crime against Greece, and you are absolutely right. I know that heads of government of my own party also took part in this unding. Unfortunately, it is not the right regulation to raise this issue, but I agree with you on the matter. If the Port of Hamburg were to be sold, we would send them to psychiatry. Secondly, I understand the criticism of workers' rights, mostly from my own friends. I'd like to have more written in too. But here too, of course, this has not been a regulation in this area, but we have looked together with trade unions in Italy, Croatia, Slovenia and Germany that we at least mention the things and ask those who are responsible to take care of the fact that workers and jobs are also important for Competitiveness. One thing, however, I do not understand what my Polish colleague said earlier: why our ports are now supposed to be worse off in international competition, because there is more transparency for customers. Why our ports should be worse now because there is a complaint body, because there are many more user rights. I just don't believe that. Finally, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs, who have worked with me very, very constructively. I would like to include the Greek PPE-DE colleague Koumoutsakos — and also — because they are no longer in Parliament — Georg Jarzembowski and Willi Piecyk — because he is no longer there. And I would like to thank the stakeholders and the Commissioner. Commissioner Bulc, if If you had not suddenly and unexpectedly chosen a very pragmatic path — in our experience with the Commission — if we were not here today and would not, so to speak, 'celebrate' the end of the discussion. To those from the UK who never wanted to listen, who never wanted to join, who found everything bad at the beginning, unlike other colleagues from the same country who wanted to improve something, I say: be glad to be out until that comes into effect.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much Mr Fleckenstein, especially your greetings for Georg Jarzembowski, from Hamburg, by the way. I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 December 2016.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item of the order of the day is the debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Council position adopted at first reading drawn up on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down detailed conditions for fishing for stocks deepwater in the North East Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002 (11625/1/2016 - C8-0427/2016 - 2012/0179 (COD)) (rapporteur: Isabelle Thomas) (A8-0369/2016).

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, this deep-sea fishing regulation is a highly symbolic regulation, which has been a lot of ink. One might sometimes wonder why, and yet the answers exist. First, because we are at the heart of the issue of sustainable development, that is, at the heart of the famous triangle that should be equilateral, defined in Rio, between environment, economy and social. Deep sea fishing is an economic activity that includes, in addition to the social function of its jobs, also a social function of food, and which, of course, has a strong environmental impact. But beyond that, there is a great concern among our fellow citizens about what we will do with our oceans. Since 2012, when the proposal to ban deep-sea fishing came from the Barroso Commission, it has been said — at least I was sure — that sustainable development, which is often only a slogan, could be brought to life the certainty that a compromise was possible — not necessarily a compromise between political groups, that is always possible, or almost possible — but a compromise on the major issues, namely, the vulnerable seabed to protect, the species to protect, but also economic activity and its jobs and the food function. It must be said that there has been a lot of noise, a lot of fury, torrents of insult, death threats I have been subjected to, incredible pressures, but, yet, we have worked in the European Parliament and in the Council, and we have reached an agreement that — I believe so — meets our priorities and all these objectives. What are the results? First of all, the maintenance of activity. It's not nothing, it was still 760 ships. Secondly, the freeze of the footprint, that is, the definition of an area where we can continue to fish in the deep sea, but which is limited to that which was in force between 2009 and 2011. A bathymetric limit that will prohibit fishing below 800 metres deep. Strengthened control and penalties for this specific fishery. A very exceptional scientific vigilance in fishing activity, with 20 percent of this activity which will be covered by scientific observers. Numerous impact studies and catch records, including non-target species. True, we did not choose ease. It would probably have been much simpler to do what the Barroso Commission had proposed, namely to ban everything, or even simpler, just as simple at any rate, to allow everything. From a legal point of view, this would have been quite easy. This is what explains the difficulty and technicality of this regulation, is that precisely we wanted to try to bring all these requirements and all these issues together. This also explains why the Council took two years to agree, which was crossed by numerous contradictions. This also explains why we used two Council Presidencies and, in this regard, I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency, which initiated this work, and the Dutch Presidency, which concluded it, who accompanied us for nine months — during a gestation — and five trilogues. But, of course, it is primarily my colleagues and their teams and the teams of Parliament that I would like to thank tonight. We worked at a high level of technicality, all together. We worked nine months, more than ten meetings of shadow rapporteurs, we have been a bloc vis-à-vis the Council, even though our positions were not always distant. In conclusion, I would like to tell you that the reason I am happy is that there are only two losers. There will be only two losers in the vote, I hope: those who wanted to ban everything and those who wanted to authorize everything so that the profit be the only rule. Those who won are those who refuse to allow the three angles of the sustainable development triangle defined in Rio to sink into the Bermuda triangle and believe that human intelligence can triumph.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission and my colleague, Karmenu Vella, I would like to thank Parliament for its role in reaching the successful and balanced conclusion of the deep—sea access file. The Commission fully endorses the compromise found between the co—legislators. Deep—sea fisheries account for only one percent of landings from the North—East Atlantic, but I know that the economy of a number of fishing communities depends to a certain extent on these fisheries. The compromise therefore reflects both the need to protect the marine environment and the interest of the fishing industry in continuing deep—sea fishing. The agreed measures, such as fishing within the footprint and the 800m depth limit for bottom trawls, the observer scheme and the control measures will make deep—sea fishing more sustainable and more environment friendly.  Deep—sea fisheries have only been regulated since 2003. Before this, the fisheries were largely unregulated and partly showed typical symptoms of the ‘race to fish’ problem, resulting in the depletion of stocks. Ensuring sustainable fishing is increasingly important for society at large, but it is fundamental for the fishermen that depend on these fisheries. We all have an interest in ensuring sustainable fisheries, and with the deep—sea regulation we have taken an important step to ensure a sustainable framework for deep—sea habitats and fisheries. In this context, I would like to give you an example of the roundnose grenadier in the Celtic Sea and the English Channel. This is the only stock for which we have full scientific advice. As a consequence, in November this year the Commission proposed to the European Council to set the fishing opportunities for this stock at maximum sustainable yield levels. In the New Year, the Commission will start preparing proposals for the next steps of the implementation of the Regulation, establishing the footprint for deep—sea fishing and identifying vulnerable marine ecosystems to be closed for fisheries. I started by thanking you all for making this agreement possible because such important steps are only possible through common effort. Let me, however, end by giving special thanks to Mrs Thomas, as rapporteur, and her team and the shadow rapporteurs for their outstanding work on this file.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, the political agreement we are discussing today closes a four-year cycle of intensive political and technical negotiations. I have always said that for an agreement to be considered satisfactory everyone has to be partially dissatisfied, and this is no exception. We are not fully satisfied. Above all, we welcome a set of ambitious measures that strive to improve the sustainable exploitation of these vulnerable species, as well as the protection of vulnerable deepwater marine ecosystems. However, there are aspects that we cannot be satisfied with. This is the case with the arbitrary prohibition of any bottom trawling activity — including exploratory — below eight hundred meters. A ban that is too drastic, without any basis and, of course, without any solid scientific support, which is a bad precedent. How can we explain to a bona fide operator that he is carrying out perfectly legal and well-regulated fishing that from tomorrow he will not be able to operate in certain fishing areas? Isn't it easy? Well, no. But neither is it explaining to the international community that the European Union imposes rules not sufficiently supported by science. If this is difficult to explain, more so was the previous Commission's claim, happily amended by Commissioner Vella, to totally ban a fully legal fishing activity on grounds of environmental protection. It doesn't have to be inferred from my words that I disagree. No. I'm very glad to have reached this agreement. It was a very difficult deal. I congratulate the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs. We have all made a great effort; at the critical point we made courageous concessions, and what I hope and trust is that with this work we can move forward.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, the distribution of marine species knows no borders. In the case of deep-sea species, the problem is even more complex. Scientific research has long shown that deep-sea habitats and species are intrinsically more vulnerable because they generally have great longevity, late maturation, low reproduction and few natural enemies. In some deep-sea fisheries, such as those in the North-East Atlantic, the Azores and Madeira archipelagos, restrictions on industrial trawl and gillnet fisheries have been implemented for many years. The habitats and ecosystems of this region are of the same nature as those of the international waters of the North-East Atlantic. This regulation, which we are debating here today, extends some of the rules that were implemented for Macaronesia 11 years ago through European Commission Regulation No 1568 of 2005, but falls far short of it. It was perhaps the possible consensus document and I therefore welcome the rapporteur for her effort. It is already some advance that fisheries below 800 metres and vulnerable marine ecosystems below 400 metres are prevented. By reducing the damage trawling causes to cold coral reefs and deep-sea sponges, we are preserving a millennial legacy and, at the same time, helping to protect the reproduction and sustainability of fishing springs. But we could have gone further, and I fear that, having not done so, the small-scale fishing of the archipelagic regions will continue to affect, for example, given the connectivity of the oceans.

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! The ecosystem of the depths of the seas and oceans, or the world of cold-water corals, sponges and deep-sea fish, has formed for thousands of years due to extreme conditions: lack of light and oxygen, low water temperature. Deep sea fishing is unfortunately slowly destroying this sensitive ecosystem. Keep in mind that deep-sea fish grow very slowly, mature late, have low reproduction and are long-lived, for example, the Atlantic throat (orange roughy) lives up to 150 years, and the ability to breed only acquires between the ages of 25 and 30. However, the current regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is a great opportunity and hope to protect the marine and ocean depths, while creating prudent and frugal management of the fishing fleet. Deep-sea resource management must be sustainable and coherent, consistent with scientific guidelines, and should effectively protect this unique ecosystem.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, I would like to thank all of us who have been involved in achieving this Agreement for the effort made to adopt this Regulation on deep-sea fisheries, and especially the rapporteur, Mrs Thomas. This is a balanced standard, which combines the obvious need to protect an ecosystem that is vulnerable and critical to life at sea with a rational exercise of trawling in European waters. All available scientific reports indicate that deregulation up to 2002 led to overfishing, and that the regulation adopted then failed to end it. This Agreement is the result of a negotiation which began in 2012. After a laborious and complex process, it brings us closer to the most stringent international standards of protection. The Regulation is in line with the activities of our fleet in European waters. Activities in international waters are also covered by the North-East Atlantic Fishery Commission. The prohibition of activity below eight hundred metres for the trawling fleet provides, together with measures such as the determination of fishing areas, mandatory impact assessments or a total ban on certain vulnerable marine ecosystems, a framework which has as its main objective to ensure the protection of of the environment, the basic pillar for any fishing activity to be sustainable. Control measures have also been strengthened by requiring the declaration of all catches and establishing an observers programme to ensure that data collection is homogeneous and accurate. We hope that we will definitely move from words, from good words, to deeds.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, this discussion on the regulation of deep-sea fisheries in the North-East Atlantic has been going on for more than three years. The compromise that has now finally been reached is reasonable from the point of view of the proposed objectives and the solutions proposed, which, in our view, was not the case with the European Commission's initial proposal. Freezing the fishing footprint by restricting the action of considerably impactful gear to areas where this impact can no longer be avoided, while taking specific measures to protect vulnerable seabed ecosystems, seems to us from the outset to be sensible and appropriate. We also value the adoption of measures to improve scientific knowledge, strengthening it to better support political decision and impact assessment processes. However, we would have liked it to have been possible to go further in the field of international waters, where fishing activities are being carried out today, which had to be subject to stricter regulations, thus benefiting, for example, the resources that evolve in the waters of the autonomous regions of the Azores and Madeira.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Madam Commissioner! First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Thomas, for having succeeded in completing this important legislation that began already last term. With fishing vessels becoming increasing, larger and more efficient, the availability of wild-caught fish has become increasingly worse. We fish up ever smaller fish, fish ever further out to sea and ever deeper down. In order for us to eat fish in the future, the management of our oceans and our shared fisheries resources must radically change and improve. It applies to stopping poaching fishing and overfishing leading to the depletion of our seas. The environments in the deep parts of our oceans are ecologically vulnerable. Because the environment is so deep cold and without light, everything happens very, very slowly. The species that live deep down in the oceans grow slowly, reaching their age of reproduction several decades later. Therefore, they are very vulnerable to overfishing, as it can also take several decades, even centuries, before that fishing stock reaches its original size after suffering overfishing. Therefore, deep-sea fishing can be more likened to mining than fishing of a renewable resource. There is a large wealth of corals and other vulnerable species that must be protected. Most of deep-sea fishing is carried out using highly destructive gear — such as bottom trawling. Therefore, I am very pleased to note that this law does not allow bottom trawling below a depth of 800 meters. It is an important step in protecting the important marine environment. Thank you!

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have finally reached the final vote on this dossier after years of negotiations. The troubled path of this proposal arises from the conflict between two very broad interests: on the one hand the economic interest of a fisheries that, by its nature, is almost exclusively industrial and, on the other hand, need to protect environments that today risk becoming the new frontier land. The strenuous struggle that has been waged in the negotiations was aimed, as far as I am concerned, precisely at that. For this reason we greet with great satisfaction the limit of the 800 meters under which no trawling can be carried out, a limit that passes to 400 meters in the case of areas with particularly ecosystems Sensitive. These are largely unexplored and little-known environments, yet to be understood ecosystems that we know to be very delicate and fragile: especially for this reason we must be absolutely cautious when we consider them as an asset to exploit. Never as in this case should we assert the precautionary principle, and I am not just talking about fishing. We think that in this case, thanks to the work of the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur, a good compromise has been achieved and we will therefore support this report.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, deep-sea fishing has given rise to passionate debates because of its impact on marine ecosystems. The current regulations included restrictive technical measures, but also the prohibition of fishing in certain areas. Despite these efforts, catch levels have been constantly reduced. Indeed, the high vulnerability of these particular stocks leads to a long, if not impossible, recovery. Bottom trawls also result in high levels of bycatch. Finally, it is also difficult for scientists to determine with certainty a sustainable level of fishing. It was therefore decided to adjust the regulations again to limit the adverse effects of this fishery. It now provides for a ban on trawling below 800 metres deep, freeze the footprint, i.e. the obligation to fish only in areas already exploited, the strengthening of on-board controls and penalties and, finally, the presence of scientific observers on board 20% of the vessels. Although strict, these measures should better protect marine ecosystems and preserve sustainable fisheries, so I will vote in favour of them.

name: Alain CADEC
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the adoption of this report, which is the culmination of four years of fierce negotiations on deep-sea fishing activity in the European Union. Congratulations to the rapporteur. On the basis of a radical proposal, the European Parliament and the Council have succeeded in defining a clear and balanced line for fishing for deep-sea species. We have had the heavy task of finding a compromise between, on the one hand, our environmental ambitions for the safeguarding of very slow ripening species, as well as the preservation of vulnerable ecosystems, and, on the other hand, safeguarding regulated targeted fisheries and incidental fishing necessary for some of our European regions. This agreement will enable the collection of data essential to knowledge of the seabed and species that are still too unknown, thanks to the presence of observers on board ships. In addition, fishing vessels are only allowed to fish within the historic fishing footprint. When they encounter vulnerable marine ecosystems between 0 and 400 metres deep, they must now move away from them, at least 5 nautical miles, and report them to national authorities. These areas will then be closed to fishing. I am delighted that incidental fishing is allowed up to 11.5 tonnes per year while being supervised and controlled. We have achieved a balanced agreement with respect for the marine environment that makes it possible to strengthen the sustainability of fisheries, starting with an awareness of the vulnerability of the European and global seabed. We have sought and obtained an economically and ecologically sustainable and deeply European agreement. Thank you Emilie for all that you have helped me do in this house since 2009.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of Commissioner Vella today. I would first of all like my colleagues who preceded me to congratulate the rapporteur, Isabelle Thomas, my colleague, but all the shadow rapporteurs also on reaching this important and great agreement. As someone who has said before me, I think that is a great deal because we are all partially satisfied. I would therefore like to highlight some of the points. The deep-sea fisheries of the North-East Atlantic are dominated in part by Portugal's traditional coastal fleet and by the itinerant fleet of France and Spain. A good number of that fleet is affected and we should take this into account, along with the important sustainability that has been added. Among the main points agreed is the ban on trawling beyond eight hundred metres in Community waters, leaving out international waters, which created significant discrimination for the European fishing fleet. In addition, the coverage of observers on board is around 20 per cent. I think it's a big deal. To congratulate again all those who have intervened in it. And, of course, I think we can be satisfied because that wrong decision by the Commission, four years later, has been changed.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, Mario Draghi said ‘whatever it takes’. I believe him. The EU will do anything to preserve its pet projects, whether the euro or the common fisheries policy. This means they will play any trick, no matter how underhand, sly or destructive of democracy. They know there is a great repeal bill planned by the UK’s Tory government. They therefore know that all the new rules and regulations they can get through over the next couple of years will be imposed on the British people, in some cases for decades. The greatest EU con for my country, Scotland, and our neighbours, England, is the infamous common fisheries policy. The EU plans to use May’s misguided bill to give it an afterlife in the North Sea and the North East Atlantic. Well, we have spotted your cunning plan and that is why we will oppose all those apparently obscure measures. It also tells us why the British Government is foolish and idiotic if it accedes to Labour, Lib Dem and ‘remoaner’ demands to reveal its hand in advance of the negotiations. Shame on you. Shame on them. Let us get out of the European Union now.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her great work. Finally, after four years of intense political and technical work, a balanced compromise agreement has been achieved. The cornerstone of this agreement between the Council and Parliament is banning bottom-trawling, which targets deep-water species at depths of more than 800 m. This new provision will protect delicate marine ecosystems of the deep sea and I fully support it.  The principle of ‘footprint freeze’, restricting activities to the areas where fishing took place between 2009 and 2011 was also agreed. The non-application of the regulation to NEAFC, a red line for EPP, was also agreed; provisions were approved including the recording of all catches to improve monitoring of these fishing activities. Member States will also be required to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems, and the Commission will assess this data annually and adapt the allowed fishing area accordingly. With all these objectives reached, I can fully support this deal.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Isabelle Thomas on her success in carrying a dossier that is anything but simple. The main objective was to protect, however, through sustainable fisheries, a particularly fragile habitat, where fish stocks are depleted and where there are species that breed very much slowly. Among the novelties are the ban on trawls below 800 metres and also the limit that moves to 400 meters deep in the most vulnerable marine environments. Fishermen will also have to communicate the number of sponges and corals caught as, at a certain amount, they will be required to move to other fishing grounds. Finally, new transparency rules have been put in place, including the requirement to make public the information collected and beyond: 20% of boats will be required to have an observer on board to allow scientific data to be collected. The new rules will apply mainly to vessels operating in the Northeast Atlantic. True, better can always be done, but after more than four years of work eventually a fair balance was struck between the needs of fishermen and the need to safeguard marine habitats.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, the Commission's initial proposal in 2012 called for the eradication of trawling for deep species. It was a very radical proposal, not based on scientific reports, and did not take into account the enormous social and economic impact of such a ban. Finally, the initial proposal has been improved and its scope has been reduced. That is why I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Thomas, on the compromise reached. But there are still certain points that I cannot fully agree with. They were already mentioned earlier, especially by my group coordinator, Mr Mato. I would like to highlight two of them. First, the ban on using bottom trawls below eight hundred meters. While it is better than the total ban on its use, this decision is not based on solid scientific studies. Secondly, the obligation to have observers on board 20% of Union vessels using bottom trawls. This measure is excessive and will put a heavy burden on the sector. I'm done. Demonizing fishing gear is a mistake. In order to achieve sustainability, the solution is not to prohibit but to regulate well, and also to take into account the socio-economic interests of the sector.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
