text: Mr President, this is a good agreement guaranteeing sustainable activity in the North-East Atlantic and is the result of intensive negotiations with the Council, which comes from the previous legislature, and that is why I congratulate Mrs Thomas. The Union shall freeze the fishing footprint in the area in accordance with a general limit set of eight hundred metres, which is quite satisfactory for industry and which in turn ensures the protection of vulnerable marine ecosystems. More stringent rules are laid down on transparency, a fair sanctions system for non-compliance and ensuring the presence of scientific observers in 20 per cent of vessels. Ultimately, this is an important agreement, a generally satisfactory agreement for fisheries sustainability in the deep waters of the North-East Atlantic.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — Mr President, as fish stocks are declining and technology progresses, fishing has expanded rapidly and uncontrollably to greater depths. Deep-sea ecosystems and species are adversely affected, as most of them are identified as particularly vulnerable to the effects of fishing. Deep-sea species grow slowly, live for many years, have a low fertility index and reproduce relatively slowly during their life cycle. The practice of fishing with bottom trawls used to catch these species especially in the north-east Atlantic is now characterised by the scientific community as particularly harmful to these species. The European Union must therefore reduce as much as possible the environmental impact of fishing while ensuring sustainable exploitation of deep-sea waters. Globally, it is estimated that 31% of fish stocks are overfished and that illegal and unregulated fishing now reaches twenty-six million tonnes annually, worth a total of EUR twenty-three billion. This situation must be stopped.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is essential to ensure, as far as possible, the sustainable exploitation of deepwater stocks, reducing the environmental impact and implementing the base information required for scientific evaluation. It is essential to set a bathymetric limit in order to better protect vulnerable marine ecosystems in the seabed, just as I think we need the introduction of strict rules on transparency, standards, for example, which may include the obligation to embark scientific observers and catch recording. Another key measure relates to data collection and, in particular, the requirement for Member States to provide information on the location of vulnerable ecosystems and European vessels fishing in deep water, information which must enable the European Commission to assess and, accordingly, adapt the authorised fishing areas: better if this assessment is done annually. The agreement reached can therefore ensure conditions to avoid negative impacts on vulnerable marine ecosystems and to establish better conditions for more effective data collection. I congratulate rapporteur Thomas on her excellent work.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Honourable Members for their interventions, which show that there is huge support for the agreement reached between the co—legislators. Let me briefly respond to some of the comments. Mr Mato, there is no ban on fishing below 200 m. Fishing will be restricted within the footprint where historical fishing has taken place. Exploratory fishing is possible within strict conditions. Mr Serrão Santos, the specificities of the outermost regions were taken into account. For these regions the threshold to define a target is much higher than in mainland Europe. Of course I understand that some Members would have liked to be more ambitious, for example concerning more observers on board. At the same time, I also understand that some Members find that this is an extensive framework for a limited fishery, however socio-economically important it may be. Here I would like to remind you once again that we need sustainable fisheries, both to secure a future for our fishermen and to protect our deep—sea environment. On this basis, the Commission believes that the outcome is balanced and a big step forward, and therefore fully endorses the agreement reached between the co-legislators.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, although I regret a little that Mr Vella is not with us, forgive me. I would, of course, like to answer that any compromise generates frustrations. From Mr Ferreira to Mr Mato or from Mrs Engström to Mr Millán Mon, at least to them, I would like to say two things: the first is that the agreement is evolutionary and the impact studies planned, the assessments, will make it possible to move it in the right direction, especially — and this is the second thing I wanted to say — that the scientific dimension is probably one of the most important ones relating to a fishery regulation. Whether it is the reporting of all catches, but also impact studies, scientific observers — we talked about this — all of these elements will allow us to improve our knowledge of vulnerable marine systems, but also about non-target species. So I hope that all of this scientific data, along with all these assessments and impact studies, will allow us to do even better next time and generate less frustration than those generated today. In any case, I would like to thank once again all the shadow rapporteurs, Mrs Barandica, Mr Jadot, Mr Ferreira, Mr Mato, of course, I will forget about it — here we should not do that — Mr Confronte, thank you very warmly for all the work done, with your teams of course, and thank you for the fact that, in the end, that is the reason and the rationality that had prevailed.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – This debate takes place just as the annual quota talks in Brussels are commencing. Whilst I campaigned for Scotland to remain in the EU, I’d be the first to acknowledge that European fisheries policy has failed – and that’s why I campaigned for the reformed CFP to have strong regional decision-making at its heart. Whilst Brexit campaigners have highlighted that leaving the EU will bring fisheries powers back to the UK, nothing has been said as to where those powers will lie. It is essential in my view that powers over Scotland’s fishing resources be held by the Scottish Parliament. Fishing contributes proportionately far more to the Scottish economy than it does to the UK as a whole – and for that reason the Scottish Parliament is more responsive to the industry’s needs than Westminster. The Scottish Parliament will never allow our fishing industry to be used as a bargaining chip in wider negotiations. All too often in the past, December quota talks have failed because the UK Government has given away too much. UK Government documents from the 1970s stated that Scotland’s fishing industry was ‘expendable’ in negotiations to join the then EEC.

name: József NAGY
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, it was an extraordinary challenge for me to draw up the Fundamental Rights report, and here I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the colleagues involved for their cooperation. The two major problems of last year were the crisis of managing migration and the unprecedented spread of terrorism. In managing migration, we have highlighted the responsibility of the Member States, but also the fact that migrants have not only rights but also obligations. In the prevention of terrorist acts, the emphasis is on the establishment of a Security Union. We also do not forget the rights of victims and their relatives. Let me say a few important social problems to be resolved, which appear in the report. We are focusing on the rights of the child, the most pressing is still high child poverty and the high number of missing children. In addition, it is important to point out the unjustified parting of children from parents. This can only be done as a last resort, and states must give parents more chances to improve and improve the situation of children. We are also vigorously addressing the rights of people with disabilities, as they are still suffering from discrimination in the EU. We are discussing in a constructive way the rights of minorities who are enriching European diversity. Do we realise that their ignored rights are merely insignificant concessions to the majority nations, but their denial can become a dangerous tool for political incitement and the excitation of nationalism in the hands of our external and internal enemies? A common minimum standard would greatly help to develop rights and enforce them where this is neglected for political consideration or avoided as an uncomfortable issue. In addition, we have dealt in detail with women's rights because we need to create social conditions for women so that self-realization and career building can be brought into line with the unique with their mission. In addition, we have not forgotten gender equality, as social inclusion also leads to profound frustration of many of our fellow human beings. A separate chapter describes the fight against discrimination and the rights of the Roma. It is also increasingly important that new technologies do not jeopardise our rights. In addition to the digital security of children and the protection of personal data, harassment or the right to forget about drones is very timely. In this report, we ask Member States to encourage human and fundamental rights education, e-governance and the promotion and simplification of participative democracy. Nor have we avoided the rule of law, as this is the only guarantee of the enforcement of all these powers. You respect me, Commissioner. It is very positive that the European Union, as a legal person, is acceding to an increasing number of international conventions, except for civil rights conventions. Thus, our accession to the Istanbul Convention can also be an example for hesitant Member States. I therefore propose that we act in a similar spirit in the case of international conventions containing the protection of the rights of children and minorities. The European Union must be at the forefront not only in economic and environmental policies, but also in terms of civil and fundamental rights, pointing a direction for the Member States. In conclusion, I would like to ask the honourable Members to comment on this report.

name: József NAGY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, we are all aware that these are challenging times for free societies, for Europe and for fundamental rights. Almost daily, we see challenges to our values and our way of life on things that we hold dear, that are fundamental, that enable us to live freely and in harmony with our fellow human beings. The way some people, some politicians included, talk about the terrorist threat, the refugee crisis and the economic situation, all tends to feed these worrying developments. Such discourse polarises societies and fuels division, hatred and intolerance. It also nourishes fake news, a reality seen through the spectacles of emotions and not facts. This only leads to a constant erosion of the values and principles that are at the foundation of the democratic societies and the European Union.  Allow me to congratulate the rapporteur on wide support for this resolution and to comment on some key aspects. Let me start with accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. As you know, the Commission remains fully committed to EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. The Commission, in its capacity as EU negotiator, is currently consulting with the relevant Council working party on solutions for addressing the various objections raised by the Court. This work is making good progress. On the rule of law, the Commission fully agrees that our common values as enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union must be respected and enforced. As First Vice-President Timmermans underlined at the plenary session in October, the key issue is to identify the best means to achieve this objective. In that respect, the Commission is examining the European Parliament’s resolution on a Union pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights very carefully, in line with Article 225 of the Treaty and will give this resolution the serious response it deserves.  On mainstreaming the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, systematic fundamental rights checks during the legislative process are carried out to ensure compliance of draft EU legislation with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Commission’s Better Regulation Agenda includes a fundamental rights checklist that the Commission is to use when conducting assessments. The Commission also trains specific departments to ensure application of a fundamental rights-based approach to policy and law-making. In accordance with the interinstitutional agreement, the Commission also committed to systematically introducing a summary of its fundamental rights assessment in explanatory memoranda. Furthermore, when mainstreaming the rights in the Charter in relation to disabled persons, the obligations enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities should be observed.  Now let me say a few words on the topic of migration and refugees. Full respect of the Charter and the safeguarding of individuals’ fundamental rights and freedoms have also been a stated priority for the Commission in the design of EU policies and measures in the areas of migration, asylum and integration. In particular, the further harmonisation of the Common European Asylum system will contribute to swifter access to international protection for those in need of it, safeguarding protection against refoulement and the right to an effective remedy. It will reinforce the guarantees for vulnerable asylum applicants such as unaccompanied minors and women, in terms of their reception conditions and procedural rights. At the same time, it will counter the misuse and abuse of the fundamental right to asylum, including by reducing secondary movements. In parallel to reforming the Common European Asylum System to adapt it to changing circumstances and better ensure the principle of solidarity between Member States, the Commission is closely monitoring the transposition and implementation of existing legislation by Member States.  The Action Plan on the integration of third country nationals recalls the importance of fundamental values for a successful two-way integration process. Understanding and subscribing to the fundamental values on which the European Union is built is an essential element of living and participating in the host society. At the same time, these rights also protect the third country national and foster his or her inclusion into our society.  The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights is currently working on monitoring the social inclusion and participation of migrants and their descendants in society from a fundamental rights perspective. It will publish in 2017 the results of the second wave of the largest EU-wide survey on experiences of discrimination, hate crime, victimisation and societal participation of migrants and minorities.  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities stipulates the obligation of states parties to ensure the protection and safety of persons with disabilities. It requires protecting their integrity and ensuring that they are free from exploitation, violence and abuse. The European Commission implements the Convention through the European Disability Strategy for the years 2010-2020 and will soon adopt a progress report. The report also takes into account the UN Committee’s concluding observations for the EU.  Trafficking in human beings is prohibited in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and constitutes a serious form of organised crime. As required by the 2011 Directive in this field, on 2 December, the Commission published two reports, one assessing the transposition of the Directive by Member States, and one assessing the impact of existing national law establishing as a criminal offence the use of services which are the objects of exploitation of trafficking in human beings. The recommendations in your report are very timely since the Commission is working now on the post-2016 policy framework and therefore will assess them carefully.  On freedom and security, as regards surveillance measures by the state it needs to be kept in mind that such activities by police and intelligence agencies of Member States may be based on national legislation pertaining to the protection of national security, an area within the sole competence of the Member States. Where measures of surveillance are applied by the Member States in the context of implementing EU law these States are, however, bound by the Charter. On the European arrest warrant, it should be noted that it is operating correctly and successfully in general. Every year it helps in bringing thousands of suspects and convicts of dangerous offences to justice.  Let me inform you shortly about what the Commission does against radicalisation, discrimination, xenophobia, hate speech and hate crime. Following the approach elaborated in the Commission communication on radicalisation, the Commission, together with the Radicalisation Awareness Network, supports Member States’ efforts in countering radicalisation, in full compliance with fundamental rights, promoting social inclusion and avoiding stigmatisation of any group.  The Network Centre of Excellence pools relevant expertise. It identifies best practices and issues policy recommendations and practical guidance that provide Member States and stakeholders with the skills and tools to implement more effective preventive measures at national, regional and also local level. The Commission’s contribution is focused on the internet, research, inclusive education, common values, rehabilitation and reintegration, and prisons, where it can provide a real added value, mainly by enabling first line practitioners to exchange practices and develop counter-narratives. The prevention of and fight against racism, xenophobia and all other forms of intolerance are a clear priority for the Commission. The Commission therefore assists Member State authorities to improve their responses to hate speech and hate crime. An important area of focus is countering illegal hate speech on the internet. The Commission agreed with Facebook, Twitter, Microsoft and YouTube in May 2016 a code of conduct on countering illegal hate speech online, including clear commitments by the companies to review and, if necessary, take down illegal hate speech more speedily and efficiently. We have just finalised a first monitoring of the code of conduct, which I discussed last week with IT providers and Ministers of Justice. The monitoring showed progress, but also confirmed the need to continue improving the timing of the takedowns of illegal hate speech and also transparency towards the notifying persons. Also geographic coverage in the EU is not yet balanced. I got strong support from Justice Ministers at the Council last week to continue on this path and to come back with a further assessment in spring 2017. The fight against discrimination remains a high priority for the Commission, notably through awareness-raising activities and the monitoring of the various directives in place in this area. Let me say a few words about women’s rights and children and Roma rights and citizenship - just to reassure you that I plan to conclude soon. On women’s rights the Commission is committed to priorities of its strategic engagement for gender equality for the years 2016 to 2019, which includes actions in response to challenges highlighted by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). Substantial progress in implementation of the strategic engagement can already be reported.  The Commission has also made many efforts towards increasing female labour market participation and the equal economic independence of women and men. The Commission monitored and assessed the progress of Member States in achieving equality between women and men, and provided input to the June 2016 country-specific recommendations on female labour market participation addressed to 10 Member States.  The Commission will continue to promote child-friendly justice and the Council of Europe guidelines on child-friendly justice, including through its Rights of the Child funding. Detention conditions are so far, however, primarily a responsibility of Member States, which agreed to respect the existing Council of Europe standards on the matter, such as the European Prison Rules adopted in 2006. Children growing up in poverty or social exclusion are less likely than their better-off peers to do well in school, enjoy good health and realise their full potential later in life. The efforts to implement the recommendations should be stepped up in particular for children with special needs, children in street situations, children in alternative care and so on. In the context of the refugee crisis, unaccompanied minors face particular integration challenges. Tailored education and training programmes, together with substantial long-term commitment from local hosting and integration systems, are needed to overcome the extremely vulnerable situation of these children.  Under EU law, all asylum-seeking children should have access to education within three months of filing for asylum. The EU Action Plan on the integration of third country nationals refers to the importance of early childhood education and care for the integration of migrant children. Having an inclusive setting so that children with disabilities have equal access to training, care and facilities, remains also a challenge. The recent Forum of the Child identified concrete actions such as the situation in the reception facilities, effective guardianship, which we will pursue further and I will discuss this with Ministers at the informal Justice Ministers meeting at the end of January in Malta. The Commission has no plans to present a specific European strategy on the rights of the child, since we believe that rather than new announcements, it is more useful to continue to focus on mainstreaming these issues right across all our policy work. On Roma rights, the Commission in its 2016 report on the implementation of the EU framework and the Council recommendation on effective Roma integration measures in the Member States identified a number of most burning challenges. To address them and bring positive changes in the lives of Roma, the Commission called on Member States to address urgently the enforcement of anti-discrimination legislation, eliminate segregation in education and housing and so on. The Commission is strongly committed to support Member States, ensure the necessary commitment to Roma inclusion at the European level, and use all available means to promote dialogue and cooperation. Let me conclude with several words on citizenship. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights has become a powerful safeguard, as demonstrated by its prominence in the rulings of the Court of Justice, as well as national courts. That being said, general awareness of the Charter can still be improved among national judges, as well as citizens in general. To this effect, the Commission is funding several projects accessible through the e-Justice Portal, enabling individuals to know who to turn to in case of breach of a fundamental right. In particular, in October 2016 the e-Justice Portal integrated the Clarity online tool developed by the Fundamental Rights Agency, which helps individuals to identify the competent national non-judicial bodies with a human rights remit. The scope of the tool will be further extended in the upcoming months.  We are now more than ever called upon to defend fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law with strong determination. The draft resolution of the European Parliament is an important contribution.  (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur for the Opinion Committee on Constitutional Affairs. — Mr President, because I have seventeen times less time than the Commissioner, I will be telegraphically. From the perspective of AFCO, I would first of all like to welcome the fact that the new framework for protecting the rule of law was activated for the first time by the European Commission, with the idea of ensuring the protection of the rule of law. Secondly, I would like to welcome the fact that two dialogues on the rule of law have been organised within the Council of the European Union. I recall, in this context, the resolution on the creation of a mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that we voted on here in Parliament a few months ago. Last but not least, I reiterate the European Parliament's call to the Commission to identify the necessary steps for the European Union's swift accession to the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The Commissioner has assured us that good progress has been made in this regard, but I have not understood what this progress means for years, because we do not see it.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. — Mr President, there is one point that concerns us a lot in this report on fundamental rights in the European Union. That is, how can we talk about fundamental rights without talking about women's sexual and reproductive rights? They are basic human rights: right to life, right to health, right to privacy. We must also talk about the right to legal and safe abortion for every woman in the European Union. Furthermore, we are also concerned that we are now experiencing an increasingly important boom of governments fighting women's rights, such as Poland, which is threatening to withdraw from the Istanbul Convention. That is why we call for more ambition in this report for women's rights. They are fundamental rights in the European Union and are basic human rights.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, we are here in Strasbourg and near there is the European Court of Human Rights, where judges pronounce themselves and punish the 47 partner states for human rights violations. For us, the Charter of Fundamental Rights applies with the same force and importance as treaties. However, although we as a European Union are more politicized and integrated, we have much more difficulty in punishing States guilty of non-respect for fundamental rights, as if these rights were scary, as if Europe could be a la carte, with more or less fundamental rights. For the Member States, look at the setbacks in violations of women's rights, LGBTI rights, refugee rights. On the Commission and the Council side, we note the absence of a maternity leave directive or the blocking of the anti-discrimination package. In 2015, more than 150 petitions related to direct human rights violations, and this number is increasing. What will happen in 2016? We know too well — history has shown us — that in times of crisis, in terms of fundamental rights, every time we stop moving forward, we are moving back. So let us be neither accomplices nor responsible for these setbacks, but to the offensive on fundamental rights.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, I support the draft report presented. We face major security challenges at the moment, but I think all the more needs to be monitored for basic human rights right today. In fact, ensuring security is often associated with limiting human rights. However, I am of the opinion that it is not necessary to significantly restrict human rights to ensure security. The European Union must be able to ensure both safety and respect for fundamental rights together. I think she is well equipped to do that and has no reason to step away from that goal. Hate crimes, which have unfortunately been multiplying in the territory of the European Union, are a violation of both fundamental human rights and the right to safety. Finally, I believe that the most focus must be on the quality of respect for first and second generation human rights, because these basic human rights are a prerequisite for all other human rights. I would also expect more space to be given to the issue of freedom of religion in the report, including in the context of expressions of Christianophobia, which unfortunately we have been in Europe for the last few years witnesses.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur's colleague, József Nagy, for his efforts to reach agreement and for the preparation of the compromise proposals. As you know, the annual report aims to examine the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. The European Union faces many challenges today, and these challenges can only be tackled persistently and morally by maintaining and protecting the EU's common values, such as democracy, fundamental rights, the rule of law. Therefore, these values must be protected in themselves and also in relation to other initiatives of the Member States and the European Union. In 2015, a number of Member States had problems with human rights and its various areas. Hate crimes and hate speech have taken terrifying proportions, the latter here in the European Parliament. In several Member States, the right of assembly, the free functioning of NGOs, the freedom of the media, continuous institutional discrimination, xenophobia, targeting primarily minorities, the Roma minority or the LGBTI people, or even refugees. Exclusion and vile incitement of hatred against refugees is particularly repulsive. The refugee rhetoric of the far right has flogged xenophobia and anti-Islamism in many European countries. Homophobia, exclusion and discrimination against gays have intensified in several European countries. The situation of Roma communities in Europe, who are still treated as second-rate citizens in many countries is extremely worrying. A number of European countries have still not ratified the Istanbul Convention, which could be one of the most important means of combating violence against women and abuse in relationships. These few examples also show, Madam President, how much this report is needed and how much decisive political action would be needed.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: The respect for fundamental rights is absolutely fundamental. There can and should not be any discussion about this. We must protect and promote our European values. I fully support this message from the report. On the other hand, the report dares to outline EU fundamental rights and to see its scope as far too broad. In order to preserve the fundamental nature of fundamental rights, not everything can be regarded as a fundamental right. We really shouldn't let this out of our sight. Another point of criticism is that the report does not sufficiently respect the division of competences between the EU and its Member States. A Europe that wants to be close to its citizens must take this division of competence seriously. However, I would like to end with a positive point. I am particularly pleased that the report recalls the importance of the Istanbul Convention in preventing and combating violence against women. It is now up to the Member States to do their jobs. Violence against women is unacceptable and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination which is both cause and result of gender inequality. I would add that violence against men and children must also be combated by all means.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ALDE Group. This report is an important success and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Nagy, and my colleagues from other groups for their excellent cooperation. Our work over the past few weeks and months has shown that fundamental rights do not have political affiliation, but concern us all and must also be safeguarded and protected by all of us. I have to say that, unfortunately, the text is not as ambitious as I might have wished. However, the fact that it was adopted by a large majority in committee with cross-party support is an important step. We have thus created a common foundation for respect for fundamental rights in Europe. Recent developments in some Member States should remind us that we can never take fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law for granted — especially not in the times we live. We live in troubled times, times of increasing intolerance and disrespect for our fellow citizens and those who are often looking for protection and security in Europe, times of geopolitical emergencies, political populism, including increased violence and moral protection. Uncertainty. If we are not paying attention now and really pay attention, then it may be that the rule of law in Europe is seriously threatened. That is why the European Parliament must now act more than ever to ensure respect for and promotion of human rights and fundamental rights throughout the Union. A functioning democracy is a sine qua non conditio to ensure the rule of law. It is our moral duty to do everything necessary to achieve the achievements we have fought for — democracy, the rule of law and to preserve and develop fundamental rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Madam President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur. It is increasingly a challenge to take stock of fundamental rights in the European Union and outside the European Union, as the gap between texts and reality of practice seems to be increasing. This is, of course, true for the rights of migrants, both on the territory of the Union and at its borders, and I am thinking in particular of the rights of minors and especially of isolated minors and what I will call the denial of the right to asylum and more broadly of international protection. I am also thinking of questioning the rule of law and democracy, freedom of the press, the right to protest, the independence of judges, women's rights, LGBT rights and minority rights. Viktor Orbán and his “illiberal democracy” seem to be making more and more followers. Many of those living in our territories are stigmatized and have their fundamental rights denied in the name of national or religious identities that would be peculiar to fantasized Europeans, and I am not even talking about those who call into question the European Convention on Human Rights. So yes, ladies and gentlemen, I am concerned and wonder what the charter of fundamental rights is to those who govern us.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first I would like to thank my colleague, the rapporteur, Mr Nagy, because he showed honesty and understanding during our negotiations, which brought us all forward. We know that there are still very critical assaults on the freedoms, rights and values on which Europe is based. Our goal in the report has been to point out the breach of human rights in asylum and migration, economic and social rights, minority and linguistic rights, LGBTI and women’s rights, among many others. Since 2007 the social and economic crisis has been devastating. With 60 million people forcibly displaced worldwide, the migration situation is set to remain at the top of the EU agenda. In addition, we are we witnessing a remarkable growth in racist and xenophobic incidents, which once again highlight on our part the difficulty of finding the right relationship between security and freedom. When we speak about the rule of law, we often forget the situation in some Member States which enjoy a reputation they do not always deserve. I am now referring to Spain, where next Friday the President of the Catalan Parliament will have to go to court because she allowed a discussion among Deputies on the independence of Catalonia. This is a very severe breach of the right to freedom of expression, which is universally accorded to the democratically elected representatives in our country.  I will conclude by saying that this report is not our report, but since it is in line with our concerns we will vote in favour of it.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the problem with this report is that you believe in certain universal rights. So do I, and so do most people in Europe. Unfortunately, most of the world does not. Many of the people now coming into Europe are showing by their behaviour – whether in Cologne, Malmö or Brussels – the contempt with which they regard both the rights of women and the rights of homosexuals and transgender people. You see, being homosexual myself I care that our streets are safe for all, regardless of gender or gender preference. When will the EU learn that freedom, including freedom of speech, is non-negotiable? Migrants must fit in with our values, not vice versa. And that, ladies and gentlemen, is non-negotiable too.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Freedom, security, equality and freedom of expression are all fundamental rights that the European Union claims to be so proud of. But ironically, the same Brussels elite hates the people they want to defend, the people who stand up for their own culture, who stand up for their own country, the people who want their country to guard the borders in order to protect the Dutch from profiteers, against rapists, against criminals and against terrorists, to the people who want to protect their country from anti-women violence, anti-gay violence, honour killings and anti-Semitism, in short, to those who want to protect their country from the hateful ideology known as Islam. Those people who are put away as racists, as xenophobes or Islamophobes and the politicians who are working for them are accused of - and I quote from today's report - 'hate propaganda and violent political views' when it is precisely the European Union who, through its terrible open borders policy, has brought hatred and violence into Europe. And you are trying to put concerned citizens and politicians away as pariahs with policy documents like today's and to take away their fundamental right to free opinion and free thought. But I can tell you that you will never succeed because we will continue to defend freedom, security and freedom of expression, all those fundamental rights that have been put in the rude debris by the Brussels elite and seem to apply only to a group you have selected people. And we do so simply because we have the best interests of our country, because the Netherlands is our country and must remain so.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Madam President, we can see the general state of mind in this report. It consists in treating all globalist discourse with discourse of love, justice and tolerance, and any national discourse of hate speech and xenophobia to be repressed as such. In Europe, what has escaped the nomenclature of this report, which tells us about everything — immigrants, Roma, the disabled, lesbians, gays, transsexuals, new technologies, children, old men, women, etc. — is precisely the restrictions on freedom of expression. Yet there are many, they are in politics, against all those who express reservations about immigration policy, they are in moral terms, they are also in the field of history, where dozens, hundreds of Europeans are condemned, ruined, often imprisoned because they challenge the dogmas that have been set by the victors, among which was Joseph Stalin. This is how we are imprisoned today, as they imprisoned yesterday the Poles who considered that the Katyn massacre was attributable to the Russians and not to the Germans, who had been wished to bear responsibility for it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I wish to begin by congratulating Mr Nagy on his report. I agree with him that 2015 was particularly difficult for fundamental rights in the Union. Despite some developments, structural problems remain, led by the famous Copenhagen dilemma. Indeed, the Union cannot allow any of its Member States to disregard the fundamental criteria for its accession. While it is true that each new government can legitimately change its policies, it is also clear that new majorities cannot change the nature of the state by calling into question such fundamental values as the rule of law. For this reason, too, this Parliament recently approved the need for us to establish a mechanism to constantly assess compliance with the Copenhagen criteria. But 2015 also saw violent attacks on other fundamental rights, such as security and freedom of expression. We have been plagued by terrorist attacks, which must make us reflect on the promotion of the universal values that unite us. In particular, let me stress the phenomenon of radicalisation, the effects of which can be overwhelming and prolonged over time. Not least, we have been confronted with a large number of people on our borders — here too is our matrix: the right to asylum and the right to life. Here too, Parliament has taken determined steps back in 2016, but much remains to be done, both in terms of our humanitarian responsibilities and in the common European asylum system.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Madam President, Commissioner. Members have raised many important points during this debate. I would like to use my short speaking time to draw attention to a less focused topic. Europeans like to travel a lot. That's good. But what if life threatening happens suddenly? No one can expect to have all the different national emergency numbers in mind. A single Europe-wide emergency number has therefore been in place since 1991, namely 112, but it is known to only 27% of people in Europe. At the same time, barriers still exist, so not all people with disabilities can use the number without any problems. So there's still a lot of potential here. A lot needs to be done, because in an emergency, every minute can count. Increasing awareness and easier access to 112 can save lives. It is good that the report also addresses this issue.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Madam President, terrorists are threatening the right to life, the European values that we have all built over time, sometimes very hard, and I am referring, for example, to freedom to speak freely, without fear, or to free movement. The revision of the Schengen regulation precisely in order to strengthen the borders of the European Union and strengthen the security of European citizens, whose rapporteur I am, is a contribution to ensuring the right to life. But strengthening security and fear must not lead us to the other extreme, it must not lead us to hatred. We live in a world where hatred and distrust grow every day. We must overcome hatred and fear, we must believe, dare and act without fear. In hatred and fear we can never live free and happy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Madam President. We already know how the European Commission has decided to deal with the danger of Member States becoming infected with Brexit. That Brexit won, among other things, because the xenophobic speech that there are too many Poles or Spaniards receiving social benefits in the UK? Great. The Commission is preparing a plan to limit access to social benefits for the unemployed, retirees and European students in European countries. They say it is to mitigate the feeling that immigration from other European countries erodes the sustainability of the welfare state. Of course you do. To fight it, they give the xenophobic reason. It seems that the Commission has joined the maxim of 'if you can't defeat your enemy, join him. ' I think it is very regrettable, the truth, and here we have a new violation of fundamental rights. I guess for the next report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, here is an umpteenth report advocating good thinking, politically correct, a report full of good intentions, sometimes at the limit of incantation. Everything goes there: immigration terrorism, crime, values, education, children, seniors, the disabled, trafficking in human beings or even Roma integration. You see the migration crisis as a historical challenge for our time, a positive demographic factor and, above all, the future of Europe. Rather, we see it as a serious threat, particularly to the safety of our fellow citizens, and it is not the tragedy experienced in Europe and France in recent months that will make me deny. You in the European Parliament want to set up the PNR and restrict the acquisition and possession of firearms in order to supposedly fight terrorism. We consider this to be a new and brutal attack on the freedoms of honest people, to disarm them in the face of a terrorist threat, which you have never been — and will never be — able to fight. You arbitrarily denounce a hate speech, which is increasingly present on the political scene, a growing Euroscepticism and political positions described as violent and dangerous for European civilization. We see it as a hope. You are witnessing a powerful revival of the European peoples, who reject your obsolete and ineffective solutions. Like the unelected President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, begging European governments to stop holding referendums, you despise the sovereign expression of peoples to impose a moribund ideology on them. Ladies and gentlemen, open your eyes wide, Europeans no longer want your solutions and your eternal lessons of morality!

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I welcome the report's findings on minorities and I am pleased to note that the text sets out a number of facts by which the European Union has long been in debt to national minority communities in its territory. Such a statement is that when solving the problems of minorities, it is necessary to establish minimum standards for the protection of the rights of minorities. Similarly, it is important that the text is itemized to promote the full equality of these communities in all areas of economic, social, political and cultural life. The report calls on the Commission to establish a policy standard for the protection of minorities, as the protection of these groups is part of the Copenhagen criteria, which also apply to the Member States. The text urges the Member States to exchange good practices, emphasising in particular that administrative reorganisations should not have a negative impact on minorities. I sincerely hope that, by adopting this report, the Commission can be encouraged to listen to the problems of national minorities and to engage in proactive behaviour, because ignoring the provisions will be affected by the authority of the entire Parliament. It is time for the European Union to respond to its 50 million citizens belonging to a national minority and convince them that it listens to their situation and is ready to demonstrate this through actions and legislative initiatives.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Fru ordförande! Fru kommissionär! I will speak in English. We Europeans often take pride in being one of the most developed communities in the world, a community which is actively fighting for the protection of fundamental rights and for safeguarding non-discrimination for everybody. Where children have the same life chances, regardless of the family they are born into, and their parents have equal opportunities in the public spheres of life. However, what we see through the latest EU Minorities and Discrimination Survey (EU-MIDIS) of the fundamental rights agency is that 80% of Roma parents and their children surveyed live in poverty compared to 17% of the general population. That every third Roma child goes to sleep hungry at least once a month. That every third Roma lives in a house without tap water. Every second Roma family lives without a toilet, a shower or a bathroom. That 63% of young Roma are not in work, education or training, compared to the European average of 12%. It is high time we became suspicious about how well designed our policies really are, how much we have achieved in the field of non-discrimination, and then we can really talk about fundamental rights for everybody in Europe. We have to tackle the anti-Gypsies.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: — Mr President, the draft report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU 2015 contains a lot of important perspectives on the problems of different populations and minorities. What is surprising, however, is that the issues of older people have been dealt with in just a few lines. Don't you want to see ageing people's distress? The people are getting older in Europe and the birth rate is at very low levels. Small age classes are having to worry about a growing number of aging people. Member States suffering from economic difficulties have had to save on basic services, and this also applies to the elderly. Lonely elderly people in particular become easily neglected in many ways. All ageing citizens are entitled to precious old age, but this is not going to happen. That is why I would like to see more of the problems of the welfare of the elderly raised in the report on this day.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Madam President, I welcome the report, which, as in recent years, points to the EU's lack of fundamental rights. One of these unresolved EU problems every year is the situation of indigenous minorities. For many years, we have been asking the Commission, together with my colleagues from the national minority, to establish European minimum standards for the protection of the rights of minorities. In vain. The Commission deflects responsibility by saying that this is a national competence and can not do anything. However, while the Copenhagen criteria require accession countries to ensure the protection of minorities, discrimination against national minorities is often overlooked if it is committed by an EU Member State. Think, colleagues, how a minority can expect redress from a national majority that wants to discriminate against him. It is naive to expect this, a solution must be found here at European level and pressure must be exerted on the Member States. Minority rights are fundamental rights and are an integral part of them; they simply cannot be circumvented. This is also covered by Article 2 of the Treaty of Lisbon. It is feared that the challenges caused by the migration crisis will have a negative impact on the situation of indigenous minorities. The migrant issue must not distract attention from the problems already existing. Madam President, national minorities represent and cherish European culture and values. EU citizens, who make an integral contribution to the diversity of the Union, only unfortunately in some cases want to be treated as second-rate EU citizens. This should not be tolerated.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Nagy for his work and for the space devoted to the rights of children in his report. In 2015, in fact, many events in the European Union have shaken our consciences, showing trampled fundamental rights and mortified human dignity, and this also with reference to minors, whose rights They should, on the contrary, always be protected. Several times in this House, we have stressed that in the context of migration, reception policies must always take into account the principle of the best interest of the child and we have reiterated, in In particular, that foreign minors cannot be subject to any form of detention related to their status as migrants, as unfortunately has happened in some member countries. It is necessary to protect minors who are alone on the territory of the Union: in fact the absence of adequate safeguards in reception facilities often drives a large number of minors, over ten thousand According to Europol data, to move away, thus exposing themselves to serious risks, such as recruitment into criminal groups, sexual exploitation and exploitation by human traffickers. But more generally, poverty, lack of access to education, marginalization, exposure of children to violence towards women in the family area, what, this, for children extremely traumatic, These are just some of the serious violations of children's rights unfortunately still perpetrated in Europe today. The Union must intervene on all this.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Colleagues and Colleagues! I would like the report to be focused on the application of fundamental rights by the Union institutions themselves, on respect for property, economic freedom, on good administration, which is also one of fundamental rights. Meanwhile, the report does not focus on what belongs to the European Union, but on the member states, and makes several mistakes. First, it is unauthorised to intervene in matters of family legislation, in the right to life, which belong to the Member States. Secondly, here we are dealing with a dubious interpretation that so interprets freedom broadly that it prevents the active struggle for the safety of Europeans. Finally, when it comes to national minorities, Poland is a country that gives an example of broad protection of the rights of national minorities, and I would like other countries to apply these types of standards. It is therefore worth exchanging experiences in this regard.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: — Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, populism, xenophobia, racism, hate speech, ultra-nationalism and denial of the different are the elements, pointed out in this report, which make up a very dark landscape for fundamental rights in the European Union. And I would like to emphasize three imminent challenges. The first is that of social inclusion and the struggle for the integration of migrants and refugees, which is a dynamic and multidimensional process, but which requires the Member States that deny solidarity and seek to build walls for those fleeing war and violence. Second, the challenge of equality, particularly for women; the rights to sexual and reproductive health, which also include the right to voluntary termination of pregnancy, some of whose denials could entail serious violations of human rights. And the third point is the fight against all forms of discrimination: against the LGBTI collective; against the Roma, against the Roma population, threatened by attitude against the Roma; against the Muslim population, threatened by Islamophobia. And, as chairman of the Intergroup against Anti-Semitism, I would like to point out the importance of paragraphs 53 and 54 of the resolution, the rise of hate speech. Attention, Commission! It is not only necessary to promote the founding values of the European Union. Active work and commitment must be made to ensure that the European Union continues to promote an open, pluralistic and inclusive society.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, during 2015 we have seen an increase in the incitement to hatred and an increase in xenophobia and other forms of injury in important areas of society. The migration emergency, the arrival of a large number of asylum seekers and immigrants, but also terrorist attacks, have accentuated the manifestations of hate in a racist and xenophobic background and discrimination. In some cases, the request for help was answered by erecting walls of barbed wire, but Europe has also been able to show great solidarity and welcoming capacity. However, the situation remains difficult and requires an effort on the part of the European Union to reiterate that we are a community based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, of the rule of law and respect for human rights. Member States of the European Union should supplement their efforts with proactive policy initiatives, drawing up plans specifically aimed at promoting and awareness of rights.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: — One of the history of the very famous Middle East teacher once criticized the legal experts of his time for incarnating mosquitoes or mosquitoes in a glass but swallowing a camel. They were senselessly engaged in trifles, but they were reprehensibly eluded the overall picture. This report also has a number of such 'mosquitoes', such as trying to push through a dubious anti-discrimination directive or the Istanbul Convention, violent acceptance of so-called 'same-sex marriages', making abortion a fundamental right and migratory measures that only aggravate the situation. The authors of the report have criminally thrown away the opportunity to strengthen the right to life, highlight the evil of human trafficking, FGM and discrimination against people with disabilities and ethnic groups. As shadow rapporteur, I appreciate the hard work of the rapporteur, who has tried to keep our unity in diversity. But, unfortunately, the camel in this drink passes more and more national sovereignty to the institutions of the EU and the Council of Europe. It's time to say goodbye to such a message and focus on real fundamental rights in our nations. Watch out for the camel in the glass, or we'll choke on it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President. I would like to thank Mr Nagy for the breadth with which he has worked on this report on the situation of fundamental rights in Europe, which is, in my opinion, the most inclusive and open document that Parliament has devoted to this issue in recent years. I think it contains constructive criticism and a clear description of our opportunities for improvement, which almost always focus on eliminating the gap between what States proclaim and what they do. That difference fuels the tragedy of refugees, inequality, progressive disarmament of the European social model or the bankruptcy of principles that lie in our Charter of Fundamental Rights. I am very grateful for allusions such as those made to historical memory, respect for cultural diversity or non-compliance with framework decisions that are key to victims or criminal policy in the Union. I hope now that those referred to will apply to appearing with better qualifications in the next report.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). — 'Protection of fundamental rights in Europe'. Yes! For all European citizens? No, of course not! Commissioner Katainen's reply to a question I put to him: “Memoranda are not subject to EU law and in that sense the European Charter of Fundamental Rights cannot be invoked in Greece.” In other words, the European Parliament is monitoring the implementation of the programme. Brilliant! It is an insult, Commissioner, to the inviolability of human dignity, the gross and provocative violations that occur with our tolerance in Greece. But ignore for a moment that I am Greek and speak of my country! Tell me which, even one of the most fundamental rights, have we, as a Europe, succeeded in being universal, inviolable and non-negotiable? The right to work? Count the unemployed! Protecting children? Count undernourned and excluded from basic education! Health protection? Count out of drugs and care! Collateral damage in the name of what vision, what objectives and what Europe ultimately, Commissioner?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). — (EL) Madam President, instead of trying to eliminate the violation of fundamental rights in countries of Europe, such as Greece, and victims of European citizens, the European Union is trying to integrate illegal immigrants and refugees into European societies, the who have no respect for these fundamental rights and, in order to do so, blackmailing, persecuting and treating European citizens who are reacting to this development as xenophobic, racist and hate vectors. But how is it possible to integrate into European societies all those I have just mentioned, the illegal immigrants who do not want to join, who come from other religious, cultural and ethnological and religious entities? These people behave as overlords and want to enforce Islamic law in Greece and across Europe.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Madam President, today we are debating fundamental rights in the EU. I take the opportunity to remember that last September, with a 77% participation rate, Catalan pro-independence parties achieved an absolute majority in the Catalan Parliament. Two million people voted for independence. Carme Forcadell was elected President of the Catalan Parliament, and she allowed a debate on Catalan independence. On Friday, Carme Forcadell has to appear in front of a Spanish Court to declare, following orders from the Spanish Government. She could be banned from public office because she allowed Catalan MPs to debate on independence. Commissioner Jourová, dear colleagues, do not be indifferent to the actions of the Spanish State against Catalan democratic politicians. Do not let Spain undermine, with total impunity, our democratic and fundamental European rights. Finally, we do not want an EU of double standards. Every day we are talking about possible violations in Hungary and Poland, while saying nothing about what is happening in Spain.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have been tempted to react to many of the comments but, due to the fact that I had a very long speech at the beginning when I tried to explain everything we do in the Commission in the field of fundamental rights, I would like only to thank you for the discussion and reassure you that the Commission remains fully committed to protect the fundamental rights of EU citizens.

name: József NAGY
text: rapporteur. — Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner, dear fellow Members, thank you for your valuable contributions and, of course, I would like to respond to all the dear speakers, but perhaps I would rather say once again that what is well known is that the annual report on fundamental rights is the European Union and to assess the state of fundamental rights in the territory of its Member States. It is clear from the comments that we encounter a lot of problems, and it is very difficult to find the border between freedom of speech and hate speech, the balance between security and freedom. It may seem easier to secure [rights and assistance] rights of individual discriminated groups, such as the rights of people with disabilities, the elderly, migrants, national minorities, even women or children. Unfortunately, that's not the case. It is our job to establish frameworks, legal systems, along which this can be done, along the fundamental rights that are generally valid. Similarly, it is Parliament's task to investigate how and how these rights can be ensured and accounted for by public and European Union organisations. Allow me to respond separately to the Commissioner's speech very briefly. I was very pleased to hear that the Commission is already preparing the accession of the European Union to the Convention on Human Rights. We have also heard that the European Commission's serious aim is to develop a comprehensive EU strategy on the rights of the child on issues such as child-friendly justice, the right to education, the rights of children with disabilities or online child protection, child rights protection. I would just like to say once again the call that I would like to propose that we act in a similar spirit in the case of international conventions containing the protection of the rights of minorities. I believe that the European Union should be at the forefront not only economic and environmental, but also civil and in terms of fundamental rights, pointing a direction to the member countries.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2015 showed no significant progress, especially as regards minority rights. I would like to draw attention to the fact that minority communities continue to face obstacles to enforcing their linguistic rights in access to justice and other public services such as education, health and social services. Member States should make further efforts to remove disproportionate administrative and legislative barriers which could hinder linguistic diversity at European or national level. I would like to encourage the Commission to establish a policy standard for the protection of minorities in accordance with the Copenhagen criteria, which apply to both candidate states and Member States. It is necessary to exchange good practices for resolving minority problems and to apply best solutions throughout the European Union. I would like to encourage those Member States that have not yet done so to ratify as soon as possible the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities and the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages, who have ratified it and adhere to it. This also applies to candidate countries and countries with an association agreement. Member States must guarantee the right to use minority languages, and linguistic diversity within the Union must be protected. I propose to reinforce the Commission's plan for education and use of regional languages, as this will help tackle linguistic discrimination in the EU.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. —I noted with satisfaction that this year's report also discusses the rights and protection of minorities in the European Union in a separate section, thanks to the amendments made by MEPs, which significantly improved the primary draft. The report contains a number of important points for the future of the protection of minorities in Europe. First of all, I would like to highlight the importance of ratification of international and regional human rights treaties, which would make it possible to establish unified systems for the protection of minorities throughout Europe. I would like to call on the Member States, which have not yet done so, to ratify them as soon as possible. I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the need to develop and adopt uniform minority policy standards, EU also to clarify the Copenhagen criteria and to apply them both in the Member States and in the candidate countries. Without these, it is impossible to develop a system for minority protection at EU level. The report also addresses the importance of minority and regional languages. Here I would like to mention one of the special aspects of linguistic discrimination, the so-called “geo-blocking”. Area restrictions on digital content, for example, prevent minorities from accessing public interest content in their native language. I sincerely hope that we will be able to report real progress in these areas in the future.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The report on the state of fundamental rights on national minorities is good. I am delighted that the report of ET 1985 (2014), the so-called The Palmar report and the call for it to be part of EU law. Furthermore, it is welcomed that the report calls for the use of minority languages in order to preserve the linguistic diversity of the Union. Similar calls are very necessary in order to curb the anti-minority trends currently prevailing in Europe, when in EU Member States the use of the mother tongue of traditional national minorities residing therein is restricted and the use of their national symbols is prohibited and sanctioned. The Commission would be expected to take action in the area of minority protection and not justify its inaction just because it does not fall within EU competence. And European decision-makers can reasonably be expected to pay similar attention to these violations and condemn them in the same way, if they look at the rights of traditional national minorities as part of fundamental rights.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. — The Charter of Fundamental Rights, which is a set of fundamental human rights and civil obligations, is the guarantor of a just society. Therefore, I am concerned by the fact that Polish and UK citizens are still not covered by these fundamental rights, as both countries do not recognise the KPP. Racism and xenophobia are worrying in many forms: Afrophobia, anti-romance, anti-Semitism and Islamophobia. There is no derogation from protecting freedom of thought, creed and belief. All Member States of the European Union must respect fundamental rights. The fundamental rights of women and girls are still being broken, even with the same protection against violence in all Member States. Further action is necessary in the fight against this phenomenon. In this context, Member States should be reminded that the mere accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence does not exempt them from the obligation to sign, ratify and apply the principles contained therein. I surprised and disbelief that Poland, which recently ratified the Istanbul Convention, now wants to withdraw from it.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: in writing. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 1948 the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted. It is alarming that, in the hitherto wealthiest era of human history, one is considering whether we can afford to guarantee the human rights of all. There must be zero tolerance for arbitrary violation of human rights in order to guarantee civilized cohabitation. Human rights and fundamental rights apply to all people, all sides and always. Human rights are inalienable — even man himself cannot give up his rights. In order to ensure that fundamental rights in the Member States of the European Union are fulfilled in accordance with the rule of law, the prohibition of discrimination should be extended to all aspects of life by adopting the Equality Directive. Similarly, when rules are applied in employment to prevent discrimination, inter alia, the accessibility of urban environments, health care or education should be ensured.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Written. — Not only does corruption weaken the European economy, thereby lowering the welfare of citizens and citizens — according to the European Commission estimates two years ago, corruption per year causes some 120 billion euros of damage to the European economy — but by violating laws and abuse of power comes also to violations of human rights. Given that because of the very nature of corruption acts, which are generally covert and well planned, people often do not realize that their human rights are violated, it is therefore necessary to pay even greater concern to raising awareness of people in which cases they are violated their fundamental rights. As a society, we must have zero tolerance for corruption.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the report by Christian Ehler and Luigi Morgano, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Committee on Culture and Education, on a coherent EU policy for cultural and creative industries (2016/2072(INI)) (A8—0357/2016).

name: Christian EHLER
text: rapporteur. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. This Parliament, particularly in the unique cooperation of the Committee on Culture and Industry, did something last year that many people wrongly no longer trusted us. We listened in Europe, we spread our arms, we have spread our arms with this wondrous amalgam from famous publishers such as Gallimard, Penguin Books, the Suhrkamp publishing company, we have collaborated with designers, dancers, writers, musicians, the independent music producers of Impala, who usually tell us for weird players with a weird Language, we have worked individually with authors in Parliament such as Nina George, the Englishman Nick Yapp with journalists, newspaper publishers, top researchers in the industry who are researching new materials and textiles, we have worked with the German Fashion Council, high-end industrial icons such as Hermès or LVHM, but also representatives Hundreds of thousands of small companies and craft businesses in Italy, Spain and many other European countries have spoken that create training, create jobs and not only retain Europe's cultural and craft heritage, but also operate globally successfully worldwide. The answers and the results of the report are clear. The three million enterprises in the creative industry provide more than 12 million full-time jobs in Europe. This means that no less than 7.5% of EU employees are employed in this sector. Turnover is more than EUR 1 500 billion, while the added value is approximately EUR 500 billion. It is a fact that this sector is larger than car production or chemical production in Europe. In addition, the cultural and creative industries have an impact on other industries such as tourism, retail and digital technology through their so-called spillover effects. This sector is making an important contribution to this sector for Europe's reindustrialisation and competitiveness. Nevertheless, there has not yet been a single definition of the market at European level, let alone a single policy for this sector. This report is intended to change this. We need a comprehensive economic and industrial policy strategy at EU level that takes into account all the specific characteristics of the cultural and creative industries and establishes a balanced regulatory framework that addresses the challenges of digitisation or the revision of copyright legislation in new growth and new job opportunities. Particularly with regard to copyright, the report takes a clear position. Modernising copyright for the digital age is probably the most important reform we can imagine to make life more lucrative for artists, creators and designers in the cultural and creative sector. The value of cultural and creative work has been largely diverted by users, rightsholders, artists and producers to the benefit of platform operators. This has to change. The value gap has created an inefficient and unfair market and threatens to seize the long-term opportunities of Europe's cultural and creative industries. The world's YouTube, Google, and ebays need to stop hiding behind the save harbour determination of the e-commerce policy. The sector is much more than copyright, but copyright is one of the crucial battles we have to fight for these people. The direction is clear: we need to make the creative industry a political priority in all policy areas. We need to improve access to finance, we need to include the cultural and creative industries better than before in the EU's funding and funding programmes. With our report we have the blueprint and a vision for the future of this sector designed. A vision that helps to boost growth and unlock the innovative potential of the sector. President Juncker has not wrongly described the creative people, the creative industries, the artists, the creative people of Europe, as the crown jewels of Europe. We call on the Commission to take the crucial steps to promote this most important European sector.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all thank Mr Ehler for his excellent cooperation, thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and thanks to the members of the two committees. The report which is tabled in Parliament's vote is not just an INI, but it is the proposal for a work programme for an industrial sector which must become strategic. Not surprisingly, it really aroused expectations and keen interest. We have come to a turning point. The age of silo policies is over: culture, industry and creativity can and should be the pillars on which to plan a new industrial policy for the cultural and creative industries that are consistent and long term, as they create a bridge between art, culture, creativity, quality production and economic and social development. And not only that: operating locally they promote the development of other sectors in the territory such as tourism, retail, services and digital technologies. The data is known, Mr Ehler has just reminded them, but I would like to add that they occupy boys and young people between 15 and 29 more than all other sectors, that these realities have resisted better to the economic crisis and, of course, they also have the element of being 95% made up of small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises. The numbers are important and studies confirm this, but if you want an empirical confirmation, it is enough to look around: culture, art, creativity and beauty are the face of Europe in the world, their specificity arises from the roots of Europe, uniqueness of European culture and arts, three thousand years of history and shared cultural heritage. Given that they will be even more crucial in the twenty-first century, it should be emphasized that they are characterized by their intrinsic dual value: on the one hand they play an essential role in preserving diversity European cultural and linguistics and to strengthen the sense of belonging to the common European identity are the vehicles through which contribute to transmitting knowledge and values and, at the same time, safeguarding the material and intangible heritage for present and future generations . Furthermore, they represent a concrete instrument, on the other hand, for social cohesion thanks to the important contribution they make to the economy of the European Union in terms of employment, investment, growth, innovation, competitiveness on the world stage. If we want to give a positive response to the dramatic plague of unemployment, especially youth, development, promotion, financing and protection of these industries, they must really enter into reality among the strategic objectives of the Union, starting with education and training. They must be strengthened in the school programmes and curricula of study disciplines such as art, music, theatre, cinema, knowledge of cultural heritage, the practices of artistic expression, the development of School-work paths, increased mobility for intra-EU students, centres of excellence. We also need policies that, ensuring the safeguarding and promotion of traditional European know-how and artistic crafts, strengthen the vocational training of highly skilled labour through campaigns to raise awareness about professional and employment opportunities in this industry and the need to have a meeting between demand and supply of work. Of course, it is not possible to imagine that this will happen without adequate funding: synergies between European programmes and funding should be developed immediately, such as the full use of 'Creative Europe' guarantee mechanism, also in combination with the European Fund for Strategic Investments. For the future, the cultural and creative industries should be considered as a horizontal strategic priority in the new financial framework and in the architecture of new programmes after 2020. Strengthening public support for European or national industries must not disdain forms such as crowdfunding or public-private partnership, but the biggest challenge remains access to credit.
