Most of these industries are small and medium-sized industries and microenterprises, their wealth lies in their creations: here the so-called “bancability” of intellectual property rights is grafted, i.e. the possibility of using them as collateral against investment loans, which must be ensured both through protocols for assessing the real value of these rights and through a more thorough knowledge of the sector by the banking system, to date insufficient. I conclude: it is necessary to make a leap in quality and become aware of the fundamental role of cultural and creative industries in the re-industrialisation of Europe and to encourage policies to support the our most precious asset, which is our European culture.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Colleagues and colleagues, cultural and creative industries are gaining importance within today's common market. Especially these days, the sector has become a door to the future. Its importance will, in my opinion, increase further. Cultural and creative industries not only contribute to the creation of new jobs for the young, to the emergence of new micro businesses, as the speakers have already discussed, but they can also kick-start new investment, such as building bridges between digital technology, science, human creativity and art. These sectors have great potential to further develop our common European cultural heritage. So the European Commission should look for remains, how to further develop these sectors, how to make them strategic objectives and priorities, and how to ensure adequate financing. So I support and appreciate Apel this report in this regard.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am very happy with this report which we strongly wanted in the Committee on Culture and in the Committee on Industry, I thank Mrs Morgano very much and Ehler for the great job done. What would Europe be without art, music, publishing, museums, architecture, design, artistic crafts, film and fashion? Quite simply, it wouldn't be Europe. Here, I think that is the deepest sense of this initiative, of this important report, which, after programmes as a Creative Europe and after the policies that have been made in some fields, we ask for really that there is finally a coherent and effective European strategy for the cultural and creative industries, which together enhance cultural heritage, represent European identity and diversity and are also the most recognizable wealth of our continent, creating a bridge between art, culture, economic activity, talent and technology. This sector, as has been said, generates social value and economic value, is based on knowledge and creativity, two intangible goods that must be protected and valued from copyright, by intellectual property, but must also be protected through training, innovation of skills and creative clusters. And let me close by saying that it is very important that there is an integrated resource strategy in this area and that, finally, the EFSI, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, is also aware of this sector.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — (EL) Madam President, the cultural and creative industries at European Union level provide over 12 million full-time jobs, equivalent to around 7.5% of the Union's workforce. However, there are even greater opportunities, more opportunities in the cultural sector, to create new jobs, especially in the countries of the European South. The European Union must therefore place emphasis on countries such as Greece, where culture, innovation and research are affected by memorandum policies, austerity, as funds for these sectors are now being reduced. We also call on the Commission to increase the funding of Union programmes such as Erasmus+, COSME, in order to further support projects for the development of culture, creativity, innovation and development.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: — Madam President, first of all I would like to thank our colleagues, Mr Ehler and Mr Morgano, for this excellent work. Finally, there is a roadmap on the table, a number of recommendations and real, concrete actions, which carry an ambitious and proactive vision for a true European strategy for the promotion and development of creative and cultural industries. It has already been said that the economic weight, as well as in terms of employment, of this vast sector of creative and cultural industries is considerable. These are largely non-relocatable jobs that have a very important attraction for our younger generations. Every effort must be made to promote and develop this sector, to protect these creative and cultural industries against the threats of counterfeiting, smuggling, piracy, and to establish and consolidate sustainable financing mechanisms through the consolidation of intellectual property rights, copyright, for example in relation to is about the cultural sector, and it is time for us to have a real arsenal and a real roadmap.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, cultural and creative industries are of key economic importance, generating more than 12 million jobs and more than 5% of European gross domestic product. But their value goes beyond figures: they take care of our cultural legacy, they are our cover letter to the world. It is therefore necessary to provide them with an appropriate environment for their development. It is therefore urgent to strengthen its financial capacity, improving its perception as an attractive sector for investment. There is an urgent need to combat piracy and counterfeiting, and ensuring fair remuneration by curtailing the transfer of value. And, of course, it is urgent to ensure the highest social and labor standards of its workers. “Digitalisation” cannot become synonymous with “precariousness”, but with development, opportunities and inclusion. That is why I congratulate the rapporteurs on this report.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Madam President, what we know about the development of cultural and creative industries, not only in Europe, but in the United States and other regions, points to the fact that they are not a factor in promoting cultural and linguistic diversity, but rather a factor in promoting cultural and linguistic diversity, but, on the contrary, a factor of cultural homogenization and menorization and dilution of cultural and linguistic particularities and specificities. This is a trend of evolution that is not dispicienda and which is not properly considered here. What is said here to be European identity will, at most, be the identity of a certain concept of Europe, which has nothing to do with the diversity and broad dialogue that the best European cultural tradition has established with other cultures. It is significant that we talk here about European and regional identity, but not about national identities, which is an essential factor of European identity. There is a clear intention to go further and further in a process of commodification of all cultural production, consistent with a vision of society that we reject, in which everything is reduced to commodity. These are conceptions that are shaped here about the place of culture in society and of cultural industries in culture, which are reductive and, in our view, unacceptable.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! The development of a comprehensive and long-term industrial policy framework for the creative and cultural sectors is essential. We need to provide adequate funding to enhance competitiveness and create quality jobs and growth. To achieve this objective, the rapporteurs report proposes a harmonised definition of the creative and cultural sector, which should be supported by statistical data. We also call on the Commission to establish a sustainable legal framework, including in the field of copyright law that is tailored to the specific sector. It is important that cross-sectoral cooperation supports interactions between small and medium-sized enterprises and research centres and universities to integrate creativity into entrepreneurship teaching and strengthening business skills. It is necessary to improve the investment environment and expand the range of financial instruments available to micro enterprises while supporting mixed financing ways, especially in the form of public-private partnerships. It will also be important to try to improve the participation of the creative sector and culture in the European Strategic Investment Fund.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President! Cultural and creative industries in Europe represent 7.5%, and these 12 million employees in these sectors not only contribute to Europe's economic development, but they mainly contribute to strengthening European identity facing increasingly difficult challenges. I strongly believe that in these times of division, we need to apply ourselves to something that we have in common, namely go back to basics: start from what may constitute an integration opportunity, namely culture. That is why I also believe that we need to build a common European public. We have local public opinion, we have national public, but we lack a European one. A room available to all citizens of the Union where we can share our experiences. My future is very much dependent on you, dear colleagues, but I know very little about your real lives. I want to know what films you are watching, I want to watch your entertainment shows, I want to know what debates there are in your countries, and thus be able to get a sense that your problems concern me. That way culture may form part of the future. Thank you!

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, on behalf of the Commission I would like very much to thank the Committee on Culture and Education and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for this joint report. In particular I want to thank Mr Ehler and Mr Morgano, the shadow rapporteurs, and Ms Comodini Cachia, the rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs, for their work and for their cross-committee cooperation. At the very beginning I fully share your views on the importance of the CCIs. They are one of the most dynamic branches of our economy. They are sources of growth, sources of jobs, and as many of you said before, key contributors also to social cohesion. I think, as you do, that the EU needs a coherent policy to support these industries, and we are currently looking into how to give a new impulse to our work on the challenges identified by the 2012 Communication on CCIs.  Let me say at this time just a few words on the four challenges identified, because many of you referred to this, and of course they still need to be addressed.  First, better access to finance. For me this is a key issue not only for CCIs. They cannot grow if, at the same time, they do not have access to finance; so of course we have EFSI and we need to really make a lot of effort to focus our CCI efforts on these programmes. There are also many opportunities with our different EU programmes, including the Structural Funds, Creative Europe, Erasmus+, COSME, Horizon 2020 but, unfortunately, and I am aware of this this, this funding remains fragmented. Creative Europe offers a mix of financial support. In the framework we launched in June last year, the cultural creative sector’s Guarantee Facility Fund; it provides guarantees and counter-guarantees and I have to say that it is expected to create up to EUR 1 billion worth of bank loans over the next six years. We see a very significant interest of banks and many other financial institutions in this new instrument; the first agreements will be signed in the coming days. In June also we launched, and I think it is worth mentioning here, a smart specialisation platform for industrial modernisation to support interregional cooperation between the regional authorities and the industry, and especially for CCIs this is an opportunity for those regions which are interested in those sectors to join forces.  The second challenge is an adequate regulatory environment. I agree that protection of copyright and related rights are at the core of the CCIs’ revenue. I have said it repeatedly: even in the digital age copyright should continue to reward creativity and provide incentives to innovate. The recent copyright reforms aim at making the marketplace for copyright fairer and more transparent. That is why we are also firmly committed to fight against commercial-scale infringements of IPRs. The evolution and review of the IPR Enforcement Directive is in the pipeline and we have established, it has to be said, EU-level dialogues between the rightholders, intermediaries, brands, civil society, consumer groups and other interested parties. We are also in intense dialogue with the audiovisual industry. The third challenge, from my perspective, is better cross-sectoral cooperation. The Commission calls for reinforced cross-sectoral cooperation around CCIs because culture and creativity cannot be seen in isolation from other sectors of the economy and public life, such as regional development, education, industry, tourism, health and environment. Next year we will launch a dedicated call for proposals to co-fund public-private partnerships which should boost innovation in the tourist sector using the potential of cultural and creative industries. Some of you also mentioned this link between tourism and the CCIs. The fourth challenge, and many of you referred to this, is of course skills. The new Skills Agenda adopted in June aims at equipping people with new skills that industry will need in the future, and our main new idea, the blueprint for sectoral cooperation, will support skills development in the fashion industry among others - because we chose six sectors, but the fashion and textile industry is in this framework. We should however also improve creative thinking, for this is one of the top three skills that workers will need in the near future. As from next year a dedicated expert group will look at specific skills, training, knowledge transfer from traditional and emerging heritage professions. On the one hand, we have to make sure that our renowned cultural heritage skills are transmitted to the new generations, but on the other hand, the digital revolution has had a major impact on heritage. New professions are emerging requiring new skills and of course, new accompanying measures. As you know, 2018 will be the European Year of Cultural Heritage. In line with what the report suggests our intention is to use this year, 2018, to give a boost to CCIs.  To conclude, again I very much welcome the joint report. Building on its suggestions, as well as on the actions we have put in place since the 2012 communication, we will reflect on a more coordinated approach to strengthen the competitiveness of CCIs. For this we need a series of clear and comprehensive actions focusing on key challenges and also on synergies with other sectors. I will discuss these actions with my fellow Commissioners. In this framework, it will be important to improve the use of and access to EU funding, maybe also through a dedicated guide and a one-stop-shop website especially created for the CCIs.  Of course we need to work together across policies, between different levels of governance, and, it has to be underlined, with all of the industrial stakeholders. I am looking forward to this cooperation.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — With regard to the Ehler/Morgano report, I am in favour of promoting the craftsmanship and know-how of the European peoples: as a reminder, in France, crafts represent more than 3 million assets, bringing together more than 510 different activities and allowing 100,000 hiring each year; these jobs are difficult to relocate and are holders of traditional and transgenerational skills. That is why I am also fighting for learning and its dissemination, in favour of upgrading the manufacturing sectors. In addition, I support the fight against piracy and counterfeiting, which is a precarious cultural industry which accounts for 3.3% of European GDP. However, the report refers to the possibilities offered by the guarantee mechanism and the Creative Europe programme, yet early estimates suggest that results in favour of SMEs are waiting. Finally, I am opposed to a European policy on this subject: Member States must be able to continue to defend their industries in order to live the know-how of the European peoples and radiate our cultural exception.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — I have repeatedly had the opportunity to say that the European Union must put culture at the heart of its foreign policy. Ficting on cultural collaboration with its internal and external partners helps to revive the image of the Union and promote a world order based on peace, respect for human rights and understanding mutual. In this context, the ICCs represent a useful link element in the strategy for international cultural relations, between the constantly evolving ICT environment and the enhancement of a stronger European consciousness, creating a sense of belonging and mutual understanding between the citizens of the various Member States. It should be noted that ICCs have the potential to create wealth and jobs with a turnover of more than 500 billion and more than 7 million people employed. This potential must be developed and not debased. they create stability and development. To this end, the regulatory framework of copyright and intellectual property must be made consistent and harmonised, with ways capable of stimulating the use of new technologies, objectives strategic to promote European core values.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: in writing. — For tens of thousands of years, art has united people living in different parts of the world and speaking different languages. Now, thanks to technology, art crosses country and language boundaries better than ever before. There should be greater support for internationalism and multinationalism in the cultural sectors. We must ensure that artists and their works move gracefully across borders — whether borders are between states, languages or technologies. In the 2010s, mobility and access to art also require comprehensive networks, cheap and fast data and a good digital market regulation. A more coherent cultural policy ensures that cultural workers receive fair compensation for their work throughout Europe. By strengthening the funding base, promoting new business models and supporting innovation, we will take care to pass on to the next generation not just debt and unemployment but civilisation, education and culture. Now if ever we need things that unite us and remind us that there is something more important in the world of money and threats: civilisation and humanity.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. - Cultural and creative industries must become a central element in the development and economic policy of the European Union. The potential of these sectors, attractiveness for young people and their added value are arguments for investing more at European level. This is why I believe that this report can be a first step in a common, coherent and constructive policy. To do this, we need to start from unitary legislation that defines opportunities, but which is not restrictive, in order to be able to maintain the innovative nature of these industries. We need to create an ecosystem conducive to creation and innovation, and this involves investing in education and training, in local development and supporting entrepreneurship or supporting the marketing of products and services offered by these sectors. I come from a country, Romania, where these industries are in full development and I wish I could say that in the future the creative young people from my country will be able to turn their ideas into reality, thanks to the European Union. In fact, we need to assume with ambition that we are willing to take a constructive role in supporting these industries now, when the European Union is still competitive and our human resource has not left yet.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the report by Mariya Gabriel, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on rights of women in the Eastern Partnership States (2016/2060(INI)) (A8-0365/2016).

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: acting rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, I must begin this presentation by apologizing to our rapporteur, Mariya Gabriel, who is currently in Gabon, where, in her capacity as Chief Observer, she is completing the final report of the European Union's electoral observation mission to that country. Mrs Gabriel would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs for the very good cooperation that has taken place between her and them, which enabled us to submit tomorrow to the vote in our plenary a very positive, very constructive and coherent report on the issue of women's rights in Eastern Partnership countries. The report presented by Mariya Gabriel is part of a genuine logic of ever closer partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, and on the other hand, the Eastern Partnership countries — Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on the other. What is the approach and what are the key messages of the Gabriel report? The stabilization of its neighbourhood is one of the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy. In order to ensure security, peace, stability and prosperity, the European Neighbourhood Policy plays a key role, respecting, of course, the principles of international law and the fundamental values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Given the foundations and objectives of this Eastern Partnership, the issue of women's rights and equality between men and women cannot be dealt with in a secondary manner. Women's rights and gender equality are, on the contrary, a cross-cutting priority of the European Neighbourhood Policy and were identified as a major and promising area of cooperation in the Riga Declaration of May 2015. For the definition of specific goals in the area of gender equality and respect for women's rights, the report proposes a quantified approach to the implications of the European Neighbourhood Policy and the European Neighbourhood Instrument. Quantified targets could be defined, for example, by country and according to the priorities chosen, based, inter alia, on the gender equality index developed by the European Institute for Gender Equality. Within the framework of specific objectives defined with the Eastern Partnership countries, we could highlight success stories, successes, which allow for deeper changes, so that the constitutional legislative provisions existing in these countries continue to bear fruit and even bear fruit more and more. more numerous. Finally, it was crucial that cooperation on women's rights be addressed at a high political level and considered a political priority. Several thematic topics — if you allow me to do so, Madam President — are firstly, the area of combating violence against women. This is an important section in the Gabriel report. In particular, we encourage Eastern Partnership States to sign and ratify also the Council of Europe Convention on combating violence against women and preventing violence against women — the so-called Istanbul Convention — to put in place real, concrete practical measures aimed at moving forward in the combating violence against women. The report also devotes particular attention to the issue of human trafficking networks. Second dimension is women's economic participation. Entrepreneurship in Eastern Partnership countries often presents itself as a default choice, despite the lack of being able to find ways of caring for and caring for children or dependent persons, also to overcome the pay gaps, which are often extremely discouraging. Support for women entrepreneurs must therefore be strengthened in a positive way through specific instruments: microcredit, training and financial advice. Particular attention should be paid to women's entrepreneurship in rural areas. Third area is the participation of women in political life. Here too, this must be a priority axis. There are still huge margins for progress; 14% of ministers and 16% of parliamentarians are women in the various Eastern Partnership countries. In this regard, it is important to underline the role of parliamentary cooperation, including the EURONEST Assembly, between our Assembly and the parliaments of these countries, with the creation this year of the Women's Forum, which has contributed and will continue to contribute to greater participation of women in political life and in electoral life. Moreover, European political parties, which very often have parties from Eastern Partnership countries among their members, should be encouraged to make the issue of women's rights and the greater participation of women in political decision-making processes a priority. In conclusion, the challenges facing Eastern Partnership countries in terms of women's rights are, in fact, common with those we ourselves face as the European Union and as Member States. It is therefore necessary to have a strategic vision and a clearer, horizontal, cross-cutting commitment that crosses all aspects and policies of the Eastern Partnership, but also defines specific objectives. Again, the goal is to achieve stability, prosperity, shared peace.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, the report by the Evop Parliament on women's rights in the Eastern Partnership countries deals with problems that we also solve in the European Union, but at a very different level. Women in these Eastern Partnership countries face much greater problems in the areas of economic dependency, unemployment, discriminatory conduct, lack of education, possibly problems with the alignment of family and professional life. First of all, it is about improving the political and economic situation in these countries. It is the very women who, in many cases, engage in civil society and effectively help with the necessary reforms. I had the opportunity to meet women from Ukraine myself, and I could see the activity of the work of their non-profits. The report rightly emphasises the need for greater involvement of women in transformation processes. Where this involvement occurred, the results were very positive, such as in Moldova the UNDP project “Women in Politics”, which the report mentions.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I am very glad that this report highlights the need to increase the participation of women in decision-making. I would also like to emphasize the importance of empowering women in conflict resolution and peace building in Ukraine.  Women must take the lead in any post-conflict reconciliation mechanism that is set up. We need women and girls to be involved in building vibrant democratic civil societies across Eastern Partnership countries – women who are leaders and role models in the social, cultural and political spheres. So programmes like Erasmus+ and creative Europe can be key cultural diplomacy tools, fostering inter-cultural dialogue and civic engagement, bringing women and girls together for the benefit of their societies. When women are included and empowered, everyone benefits.  I would particularly like to applaud the excellent work that has been done over the past five years through the tandem project, which serves as a best practice example for progressing democracy and building capacity through cultural exchange, led primarily by women.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, on this subject, the raporters and other speakers will certainly say a lot about the activities in the Eastern Partnership countries, in terms of improving the equality of opportunities for women and the situation at all, but perhaps the same words are worthy of order, From time to time we tell ourselves. It is not a coincidence that the Istanbul Convention has not yet been fully ratified, even by the Member States of the European Union, so for example, I must give the sad example of my own country as a concrete case. Hungary, too, has refused to ratify the Istanbul Convention to this day. If there is a quantified system by which we can measure the role and weight of the measures in the Eastern Partnership, I think that the same indicators would be good if we applied them to the Member States of the European Union, and then we could avoid the fact that there are two types of measure others and ourselves by standard. I would consider that a very European idea.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, thousands of women are victims of physical and psychological violence in the Eastern Partnership states with little protection under the law and almost no support services. There is a significant lack of criminalisation of all forms of violence against women, an extremely low level of reports of these crimes, very few convictions for rape and little or no funding of support services. It is estimated that two hundred and seventy thousand women are issued in the European Union, victims of human trafficking networks, most of which come from the Eastern Partnership States. For Moldova in particular, two out of three women are unemployed and two hundred thousand to four hundred thousand have been sold to brothels abroad. According to reports, this is 10% of the female population of the country. The fight against violence against women must therefore be a major issue for the European Union to address this problem in the countries of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the EU Eastern Partnership has been created in order to deepen political and economic integration within Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia. It is, at its very core, a shared commitment to democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Therefore, improving women’s rights in the Eastern Partnership countries should be the utmost priority for the EU and, indeed, progress has been made. Gender equality is now enshrined in the constitutions and legal systems of these countries. However, as underlined by the Council of Europe, legal obstacles to women’s access to the labour market persist. Barriers restrict women’s access to certain professions and gaps exist in anti-discrimination legislation. I therefore call on the Commission to undertake immediate action in order to help and significantly improve women’s participation in the labour market throughout the Eastern Partnership.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the progress made by the Eastern Partnership countries, there remain deep criticalities in the field of equal rights for men and women. Prolonged conflicts hamper the development of the region, deeply affecting people's lives and human rights. One of the most thorny issues is the plague of trafficking, which involves thousands of Eastern European women, attracted by deception by the mirage of paying work and initiated prostitution from criminal organizations. Then there is the difficult situation of Roma women, who are unlikely to react to violence, discrimination and compulsion. Weak is women's participation in political life. It is necessary for Eastern Partnership countries to do more to stem all forms of violence against women, profound institutional changes are needed. In this regard, the efforts of the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly in promoting political participation and visibility of women in Eastern Partnership countries are positive.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Honourable Members, of course, first I want to thank the rapporteur Ms Gabriel but also Ms Le Grip for presenting the report. I think this is important because it sheds a light on the many challenges that women have to face in the Eastern Partnership, but I also want to thank all of you for this exchange of views.  We are all aware that although women’s situation differs among the countries in the Eastern Partnership and the Eastern Neighbourhood, there are some common problems such as the high level of violence against women, the significant gender pay gaps and the very low representation of women in political and economic life. The Commission is strongly committed to move ahead on gender equality and women’s empowerment together with our partner countries and neighbours. The joint declaration of the Eastern Partnership summit in Riga last May clearly mentions gender equality as a key area of cooperation. The European Neighbourhood Policy review which was adopted in November last year puts a focus on gender equality and gives particular attention to enhancing women’s participation in the economy, their access to justice and social services, and to strengthening support for women’s rights. Fighting gender inequality is also acknowledged as vital to prevent radicalisation and terrorism.  The Eastern Partnership Foreign Affairs Ministerial meeting of May 2016 confirmed the commitment to the priorities agreed in Riga and the new approach introduced by the European Neighbourhood Policy Review. In addition, it called for a clear focus on delivering tangible results for citizens. In this framework, work has been ongoing to identify 20 key deliverables by 2020. Gender is a key cross-cutting deliverable to be addressed. The implementation of the commitments taken in the European Neighbourhood policy review, together with the EU Gender Action Plan for 2016-2020, provide the Commission with the framework through which we can ensure that all words are translated into real actions.  Let me just give you a few examples of this. The Commission, during the last five years, provided more than EUR 100 million that financed more than 100 projects and programmes to directly promote gender equality and improve the situation of women and girls within the Neighbourhood. In addition to this, the EU contributed EUR 5 million to the Women in Business programme. The overall objective is to promote and support women’s entrepreneurship, and more broadly women’s participation in business, by facilitating access to finance, as well as non-financial business development services in the Eastern Partnership countries. We have a very good example here in Azerbaijan and in Ukraine.  Let me also say that today’s discussions come at a very important moment for a number of reasons. First, because gender equality is one of the topics being discussed in both the current revision of the association agendas for three DCFTA countries, namely Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, and also in the development of the partnership priorities with our key partner countries. Secondly gender features as a key topic of today’s discussion in the Foreign Affairs Council, where ministers will adopt Council conclusions on the Eastern Partnership. And thirdly discussions are still ongoing on the key priorities in the European Neighbourhood Instrument multiannual programming for our next four years for the Eastern Partnership, and gender will be mainstreamed throughout support actions according to the Gender Action Plan 2016-20. The new European Neighbourhood Policy will play its part in helping to create the right conditions for positive development, lead to further strengthening the relations with the countries of the Eastern Partnership, and bring tangible benefit for all citizens, including of course women.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — One of the major objectives of the European Union's foreign policy, but also of the European Neighbourhood Policy, is the stabilisation of its neighbourhood, security, peace, stability and prosperity of all the Eastern Partnership states. Women play a key role in this regard, with gender equality remaining a horizontal priority in the European Neighbourhood Policy. In this context, I believe that countries which are part of the Eastern Partnership must develop concrete measures to ensure that the process of implementing specific economic policies takes into account the gender dimension and addresses the needs of the most deprived groups: poor, illiterate, women in rural areas, minorities and people with disabilities. I also believe that the Eastern Partnership States must promote and support women's political participation and representation at all levels of governance, the involvement of women in decision-making and in the implementation of economic policies, the promotion of Business for equal opportunities for men and women in firms and enterprises, as well as implementation of local development projects aimed at the economic emancipation of women in the Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — Madam President! I very much welcome the discussion of this report, which reminds us all that the cornerstone of the idea of the Eastern Partnership is to respect fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law and precisely women's rights. It is therefore very important that gender equality has been guaranteed in the constitutions and laws of all countries of the Eastern Partnership. Nevertheless, the report rightly highlights the fact that women remain victims of social discrimination. It manifests itself in the fact that in 2015 only 17 out of 136 senior ministerial posts were held, while gender pay differentiation is still high and reaches up to 50% despite the fact that on average women have higher education than men. For this very reason, the EU must continue to exchange its best practices through the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly and also, above all, support NGOs representing civil society. Even more so, it is these organisations, together with the governments of the Partnership States, who are jointly responsible for leading information campaigns to eradicate established stereotypes about the role of women in society. For we must all remember that even the best legal standards guaranteeing gender equality will only be a dead record if, in parallel with their introduction, there is no change in the perception of the social role of women by citizens of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: — In the European Union, we are seeing more and more tax fraud, which unfortunately have a more sophisticated form and sometimes lead them to the highest places, such as in Slovakia, even to the level of the Minister of Interior or Prime Minister. That is why it is important that we find a cure for this disease, and I consider it a simple, clear tax system to be the medicine. I am pleased that the European Parliament is taking many steps in this regard — it has already secured the exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States, but also between tax authorities with troubled countries. It is important that we simplify the system and ensure uniform registration of value added tax in all countries, so that we really also ensure that profit is taxed where it forms. I think it is also important to talk about value added tax, because this system does not bring what we expect from it and it has big tax evasion. That is why it is important to rethink the entire VAT system so that we can find a way where people and businesses are taken as little as possible, and to encourage activity so that people eventually have more left.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, because we are in the month of winter holidays and this is the time when we end a difficult year for the European Union, but we look with hope for the coming year, I will make a wish. For 2017, as a social-democratic politician who puts man at the heart of political action, I want all of us to try to do much more in the field of social inclusion. I want the European Union to pay more attention to policies for the protection of vulnerable social groups, at increased risk of loss of working capacity due to diseases, disabilities, drug or alcohol dependence next year. Summarizing, I want 2017 to be the year of investments, especially towards programmes aimed at simplifying access to a guaranteed minimum health package for disadvantaged categories. I wish that at least 20% of the European Social Fund guaranteed to be allocated to social inclusion be spent in particular on ensuring and guaranteeing access to diagnosis and treatment of chronic diseases suffered by European citizens. Happy holidays!

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President! Despite the introduction of a ban on the preventive administration of antibiotics to farm animals, both the WHO and the World Medicines Agency report that the level of antibiotics in meat has increased threefold relative to the acceptable standard. 2/3 of the world's antibiotic production is given to animals. Producing food with antibiotics, with pesticides, food additives, hormones and genetically modified products is the reason for the epidemic already at the moment, allergies, cancers, diabetes, obesity and, above all, a decrease in immunity. As you can see, bans do little with the simultaneous advocacy of for-profit industrial food production. The only way out is to support organic food requiring more effort, but much more advantageous for the citizens of the European Union. In the thought of the maxim, “You are what you eat,” they are poisoned with chemical cocktails, stuffed with products of genetic modification.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President. This Saturday, within the framework of the European Cultural Capital programme, a manifesto to defend the rights of speakers of minority languages will be presented in Donostia /San Sebastián. More than four hundred contributions from all over Europe have shaped a document proposing measures to incorporate the acquis that these cultures bring into the concept of diversity of our Union. With all the consequences. Because today, for example, only the languages of the Member States sound here, and not those of all the peoples of Europe. Even if they are mother tongues of European citizens. Even if keeping them alive has cost blood, sweat and tears. The Basque poet Esteban Urkiaga, Lauaxeta, murdered by Franco's troops in 1937 in Vitoria, recalled in his poem “Itxasora” that defending this idea of diversity is (read in Basque). Continuing that chain, we say that offering respect and recognition to these cultures is a commitment and future for us. That is why we are going to strive to bring this manifesto here.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Madam President, next Saturday the Protocol for the Guarantee of Linguistic Rights will be presented in Euskal Herria, specifically in Donostia. This is a protocol drawn up after an exemplary exercise of democracy and the participation of experts, especially social partners from all over Europe. Thanks to its contributions, the protocol contains 185 measures to guarantee the linguistic rights of all Europeans and Europeans, rights not guaranteed in the case of minority languages. This protocol is a concrete and comprehensive instrument, encompassing all facets of society to guarantee linguistic rights in practice, but also to consolidate peace and coexistence in Europe, because respecting linguistic rights also means respecting human rights.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Madam President. This is my last minute in this Parliament. A minute full of restlessness for the present which gives us indignation and so often temptation to revolt, but also full of positive passion because today, two and a half years later, I know that the European dream is still possible. That is why I would like to formulate five strategies for Europe which this Parliament knows well and to a large extent shares. One, we must step out of the self-imposed recession to return to sustained and sustainable growth. Two, it is urgent to recover the eurozone as an economic, monetary, fiscal and social area. Three, we must lead from Europe the change in the production model we need to tackle climate change. Four, we are therefore going to complete the Europe which takes full responsibility for central issues, which demand it: economy, security, defence, etc. But we also know how to return maximum decision-making capacity, real power, to the internal diversity of nations and peoples. Let us build the political space that makes Europe the engine of the new world balance between democratic and economic power. Let us move from extreme inequality to maximum equity; from state-authority to empowered society. (Speaks in Catalan).

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! The European Union has the ESA Space Agency. It sent Rosetta to the comet where the Philae lander was to land, unfortunately the lander did not land — one and a half billion euros flew into the mud. On 19 October this year, the Schiaparelli lander crashed into the surface of Mars — perhaps two billion flew. I looked at the Cassini action, which the European Agency boasted. It turns out that Europe was solely responsible for the Huygens lander that landed on Titan, unfortunately because of the transmission defect half the data was lost. I suggest leaving this agency, the Chinese are doing better, before long Nigeria is developing its own space program. Admittedly, it managed to send into space fifteen years ago the text of the European Constitution and it is not the fault of the Space Agency that this constitution was rejected and beings from other stars have an out-of-date and false image of Europe. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Madam President, Fidel Castro passed away a few days ago. In the spirit of defending European democratic values, I protest against the lenient and truthful tone with which part of the world press and some European politicians, including Mr Juncker, have spoken about Castro's death. Here in the European Parliament, too, we must say that a dictator with bloody hands has completed his earthly career, and that respect for every deceased cannot change this political assessment. If we cannot or do not want to make a clear distinction between inhuman dictatorship and democracy, we will open up space for evil and undemocratic efforts. And it is not clear what weight our word can have after such statements when we say that we support the democratisation of Cuba. In May this year I personally visited Cuba, and I found that a better, sympathetic society has been put in an inhumane and vulnerable position over the past decades. This is the true legacy of Cuban dictatorship, and it is not a sin or a mistake to say it.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Madam President, a few weeks ago I met in Asturias with José Antonio Cuesta, a citizen who had suffered poliomyelitis in his childhood and who had managed to overcome the disease and develop a full life, like most of the sick who had suffered it a few years ago throughout Europe. However, recently, new effects, new symptoms of this disease seem to complicate the life of José Antonio Cuesta and many citizens throughout Europe: muscle aches, breathing problems, great difficulties in developing a full life as they had developed until now. The treatment they are receiving from different national laws is very different, with support and recognition of the disease in some countries and with distance and remoteness in others, as in my case, Spain. I therefore want, from this Parliament, to be the voice of those hundreds of thousands of sick people, those hundreds of thousands of people who have suffered polio and who have managed to survive a very complicated disease and who need the support and support of all Europeans at the moment.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I would like to return to a very important topic, and that is Turkey and the Kurds question. We are aware of a very complex external and internal security situation that Turkey has to address. Yet we cannot agree with the Turkish government's punitive moves by which it persecutes opposition leaders and intelligence particularly around the Kurdish side of the HDP. It is the issue of Kurds that has become very burning in the context of events following the failed July putsch, as Turkey sharpens its repression of Kurds. At the moment Turkey is detaining two Czechs it accuses of terrorism only because they helped the Syrian Kurds fight ISIS. Today we met in the European Parliament with the Sakharov Prize laureates. They are two Pads of Kurdish origin. Would Turkey put them behind bars for ties to the PKK? I hope not. So Turkish logic on this issue is unaccepting. I'm all for cooperation and dialogue with Turkey, but it must not be a dialogue with the deaf.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — Madam President, the SYRIZA-ANEL government has been sucking the candy of supposedly debt impairment for months. Mr. Tsipras, every time he prepared the implementation of unpopular measures, he put the icing of supposedly debt impairment. Papers and pensions were cut up, public property was mortgaged to the lenders for 100 years, all on the altar of supposedly debt reduction. However, the Eurogroup on 5 December has finally failed to depreciate the debt, and the half-measures for the so-called short-term debt settlement are ashes in the eyes, since the debt is not only not diminishing, but the arrangements are accompanied by new harsh measures. Madam President, Greece's public debt is a carabinous shameful debt, odious debt, created by loans that did not go to the people and Greece but went to serve the interests of the lenders, to pay old debts, to be financed by the lenders, the purchase of industrial equipment and weapons and, finally, to finance the purchase of industrial products of lenders. For this reason, Greece's disgraceful debt must be written off here and now.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, there are no more words to describe the suffering of children in Syria. Aleppo is hell on earth. All of Syria is a humanitarian catastrophe. We are talking about thousands of kids that are being slaughtered and denied help. Via Skype a few days ago in the European Parliament, some boys and girls shared with us: ‘we are left alone; all our friends died’. Their voices cannot go unheard. For many of them, life has been nothing but war and siege. What if they were our children? When a Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council, Russia, blocks even a humanitarian ceasefire, what is left of humanity? We call on the upcoming European Council to act firmly for an immediate ceasefire, unconditional access to humanitarian aid, and to protect children. At least UNICEF should have access to conduct vaccinations in all of Syria. An entire generation is at risk of dying from curable diseases. Are we going to allow Sarajevo to pale in front of Aleppo? So together, tonight, we should join forces for the children of Syria to end violence. Tonight we say to the children: ‘you are not forgotten’.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, according to a resolution last week, the Hungarian Government has withdrawn from the Open Government Cooperation, an international organisation for the creation of transparent governance and the suppression of corruption. After Russia, Hungary is the second state to voluntarily withdraw from this organisation, according to the official justification, because it unjustly criticised Budapest. At the same time, it is likely that the Orbán government sought to prevent the suspension of membership of the organisation due to continued violations. I call on MEPs to uniformly condemn the alignment of the Government of Hungary to Russian standards and strongly call on the Hungarian Government to return to European values. It is time for the European Union to give a clear and tough response to the European expansion of Putin policy.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: — Madam President, Madam Commissioner, all the countries of Southeast Europe, and especially the Western Balkan countries that are on their way to the European Union, have a high overall unemployment rate. Youth unemployment in these countries is twice as high and sometimes exceeds 60%. Unemployed young people without a life perspective leave their countries and thus leave them with no chance of development. On the other hand, unemployed young people are an easy target and the target of various kinds of radicalisation, from national, social, religious and every other kind of radicalization. I therefore urge the European Commission to help find a mechanism for youth employment in Southeast Europe, something similar to the Youth Guarantee existing within the European Union.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá seoladh Phrótacal Donostia le bheith ann ar an Satharn. Is uirlis nua é seo ó eagraíochtaí na sochaí sibhialta agus an aidhm atá aige ná cosaint a thabhairt do chainteoirí teangacha neamhfhorleathana. Is buncheist bheo í an teanga san Eoraip, mar atá sa bhaile. Cheana féin tá an iomarca modhanna leithcheala á ndéanamh, agus níl aon amhras ach go bhfuil cearta teanga daoine á sárú i dtaca le gach teanga réigiúnach, dhúchasach nó mhionlaigh san Eoraip. In Éirinn, mar shampla, tá ár rialtas féin mar aon le rialtas na Breataine ag déanamh neamhaird de chothromaíocht na Gaeilge ó Thuaidh de dheasca a neamhthoilteanas Comhaontú Chill Rìmhinn a chur i ngníomh agus Acht na Gaeilge a reáchtáil. Anois, tá sé tábhachtach go seasaimisne, mar Fheisirí, go láidir ar son cearta daonna agus ar son cearta teanga. Tá ar dteangacha tábhachtach, ní hamháin dár bhféiniúlacht, ach dár bhféinmhuinín, dár n-éiceolaíocht, dár gcultúr agus níos mó.  Nuair a thagann sé go dtí ár gcearta teanga nó aon chearta eile atáimid i dteideal, nílimid ag stopadh go mbeidh siad againn; agus bí cinnte go dtiocfaidh ár gcearta leo, agus leis seo go dtiocfaidh ár lá.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Madam President. Today I want to denounce a very serious event that will take place in Spain next Friday. For the first time in a supposedly democratic European state, a court of justice instigated by the Government of Spain will call the president of the Catalan Parliament, the honourable Mrs Carme Forcadell, to declare. He is accused, against all legal reasons and meaning, of having allowed us to debate and vote on the outcome of a study committee, of a study committee! , on the independence of Catalonia. The extreme seriousness of this attack on the sovereignty of our Parliament in exercise of its freedom of expression, of this attack on the people of Catalonia elected by that Parliament, demands not only my denunciation and my rejection but also that of the European Parliament, where freedom of expression is always respected. I have no doubt that this democratic run will be followed by others. If Spain is abandoning the principles that make up the European Union, we Catalans must leave Spain, not the European Union, because we defend freedom and democracy.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to comment in my minute on the policy of thrift. This is a policy that should touch the landscape, water and soil. I'd like to stop by that last value. I, for one, would like to encourage land ownership by the smallest agricultural entrepreneurs in my minute. I think there should be a dispersal of land ownership precisely for the benefit of smaller farmers. There should be no scelling of land ownership for the benefit of the largest agronomic and other enterprises. In my court, we should approach land ownership even in terms of its acquisition very restrictively. I do not want to call for the European Union to devised new land acquisition legislation, but to undoubtedly lead Member States to determine what measures to regulate the land market are within the four fundamental freedoms in the European Union permissible. That's what we really should say.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, just over a year ago, on 5 December 2016, storm Desmond broke the UK’s rainfall record, with more than 350 millimetres of rain falling on the county of Cumbria in a 24-hour period in my northwest of England constituency. A subtropical atmospheric river unleashed devastation on large parts of northern England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland, the like of which had not been seen before. While some constituents had, sadly, experienced flooding several times in recent years, Desmond was unprecedented and, to make matters worse, was followed by storm Eva on Christmas Eve and storm Frank on 29 December. I pressed David Cameron relentlessly regarding an application for EU solidarity funds, and I am disappointed that the government’s progress on completing the paperwork has been so slow. In the immediate aftermath of the storm, volunteer groups such as aid organisations Ahmadiyya Youth and Al-Imdaad and Khalsa Aid joined the emergency services in the clean-up. But the greatest credit must go to Eden Flood Volunteers who over the past year have clocked up a total of 97 943 hours, worth more than GBP 783 542, supporting 20 000 flood affected families and businesses across nine counties, distributing an estimated 1.8 million worth of donated goods. Well done, you.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, we welcome and support the Donostia Protocol on the Guarantee of Language Rights. Stateless nations, such as Galicia, need instruments for our governments to fulfil their commitments and also international agreements to guarantee our linguistic rights, which are also human rights. In our case, it is the Galician Government itself that attacks our language, when it approves decrees such as the one that reduces its presence in teaching and expressly forbids that matters such as mathematics, technology or physics and chemistry are given in Galician. The new Spanish State education law aggravates this situation even further. Both institutions clearly infringe, among others, that stipulated in Article 8 of the European Charter of Languages. We must act now to guarantee language rights. We want recognition of our language and to be able to express ourselves in this Parliament too. We also need commitments to increase the budgets of linguistic policies, as well as support for cultural production in our language, its promotion and distribution, which will ultimately ensure linguistic policies that guarantee the recovery and normalization of Galician in all areas.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: — Madam President, I welcome the categorical victory of the Social Democratic Party of Romania at the parliamentary elections of 11 December. In a complicated regional context, this news is a good news for both the European Left and Europe in general. On 1 January 2017, Romania will celebrate ten years since its accession to the European Union, ten years in which Romanians have declared themselves among the most pro-European citizens of our Union, and Romania has benefited, although not fully, from its status as a member country. The Schengen programme, the maintenance of the CVM or the non-issuance of visas for Romanians travelling to the United States or Canada are just a few issues that the European Union will have to deal with as a matter of priority. At the same time, my country offered the European Union stability, continuous economic growth and an undeniable pro-European attitude. But my thoughts now go on. On 1 January 2019, Romania will take over the presidency of the Council of the European Union, with a social democratic government at its head. This government is the guarantee that Romania will promote common European values and principles. Thank you and happy holidays to all.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a recent OECD study mercilly relegates Italy to 34th and penultimate place in the special ranking for training skills. The worrying figure for Italy is the unbridgeable gap between the North and the South. Students from Bolzano, Trento and Lombardy score in science scores up to 35 points above average; in Campania, unfortunately, 35 points are negative, below average. This paints an actual school delay of nearly two years. Although Member States are responsible for their educational and training systems, the European Union has a support function, sets common objectives and promotes the exchange of good practice. I therefore ask the Commission not to leave any students on the street, I would ask that the evidence of the monitoring report in the field of education and training be considered and to present measures for make education systems more relevant, particularly in the sub-average Member States. We need to ensure an education that allows young people to find a satisfactory job and develop their professional careers: education is perhaps the only resource for redemption compared to a context degraded.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, at this time of the year many traffic accidents will be occurring and national authorities are making a concerted effort to reduce the number of accidents on our roads. Significant progress has been made at EU level in tackling road deaths in recent years; we seem to have had a regression in those figures.  We need to have further innovative measures to address this fact: it is notable, when you look at the number of serious injuries, that the reduction in those is lagging behind road deaths. We are not being as successful in that area: if you look since 2010, the number of people seriously injured in the EU was reduced by just 1.6% compared to an 18% decrease in the number of road deaths. So there has been a lot done in reducing our road deaths but still more needs to be done. We need now to look at serious road injuries and ascertain why we are not making progress in that area.  The Commission needs to introduce a target for the reduction of serious road injuries, and to bring forward measures in the road package next year to ensure that meaningful data are collected as to why we have this level of serious road injuries and to ensure that we are as effective in this area of serious injuries on our roads as we have been in road deaths.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, in December 2015 the Commission concluded that Georgia and Ukraine have met all criteria for visa liberalisation. This was a victory especially for the citizens, who will be able to travel to the EU without a visa. It also sends a signal to the rest of the world that a path of credible reforms is the one to be rewarded. But since then the European Parliament and the Council have been delaying this decision for months. It is only last week that they managed to strike a deal on a visa suspension mechanism. One entire year has now passed since the publication of the reports from the Commission. I believe that the EU cannot afford to wait any longer. Ukraine and Georgia are two countries whose territorial integrity is threatened by Russia; they are desperately knocking on the EU’s door, and the answer from the EU cannot be: ‘Sorry, you will have to wait longer’.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the item.
